Title: Recently I travelled for business from Cape Town to Entebbe (Uganda) with a layover in Nairobi (Kenya) return. On the flight to Uganda we flew in a Embraer 190 which is a smaller plane with 2 seats on each side (economy class) and on the return flight we flew with a larger Boeing 737 which had 3 seats on each side. Overall the food and drinks selection in economy class on both flights was good and filling enough for me, and the staff were very friendly and helpful. I also had more than enough legroom on each of the flights and the seats were comfortable. The in-flight entertainment in the Embraer was limited with 2 movies and a couple of TV shows (random bundled episodes of different shows per genre) with some music also available. On the Boeing there was a lot more content available however the sound quality was bad - I could barely hear even with the sound on its loudest setting. On our flight to Uganda we had a stop at Harry Mwanga Nkumbula Airport (Zambia) at which point I was automatically upgraded, for free, to Business Class. As you would expect, the seats were a bit more comfortable and there was more legroom available. Also, the selection of food and drinks was much better. I am not sure if I would pay the amount they are charging for Business Class, however I enjoyed the experience. Overall I am quite happy with my experience and will definitely fly with them again.

Title:
Dear Kenya Airways ,

I am on my way to Zanzibar from Bangui, with an upgraded flight to *sky priority*. The flight plan was Bangui-Nairobi (27/11, with a technical stop in Douala). We choose to book confortable Crowne Plaza in nice Nairobi in between flights. Then Nairobi-Zanzibar (28/11, ETA 9H30).

Arriving in Douala around 2pm we stayed grounded.
First we got explained that there was not enough jeta1.
Then, there was a technical issue and engineer needed instructions from Nairobi.
Then, he got the instructions but he missed a spare part.

We were disembarked around 5pm : begin of the nightmare. we had to wait till 6pm in a non AC room. Without any words of the crew or a glass of water.

Then, it was so disorganized for the passengers without CEMAC passports to get a visa : it took around 1.5 hours. I asked if we could already go and ask to the Kenya Airway office to which hotel we should go. The crew answered that we had to wait for all the passengers.

Finally the guy at the Kenya Airways office told us that we could go to Akwa Palace or Bano Palace. And that the spare part will not come before 2 pm the day after so that we ll not depart before 4pm the day after !

Then we finally got on a bus with a driver that yell on us (because nobody really knew where to go). We decided to took a taxi with my husband and go directly to Akwa Pamace (with nobody yelling at us during the transfer).

Arriving at Akwa Palace : the hotel told us that we should go to Bano Palace. Arriving to Bano "Palace" : it was so dirty, smelling bad and food was so bad... tje sheets were dirty. We got a second room that smells something like... cigarret mixed with humidity. Plus AC didn't work properly. Plus we got only one bath towel. No water in the room. It was so dirty that we went outside for dinner.

Anyway after all these I tried to call Kenya Airway' client support. I got an email during the night saying that our flight from Nairobi to Zanzibar was the 30/11 at 00.30 ... and our flight from Douala to Nairobi the 30/11 at... 20pm. PM. So we will do Douala-Nairobi after Nairobi Zanzibar, yep... everything is possible with Kenya Airways.
Wifi in hotel did not worked properly. From 4 in the morning I tried to reach via call & whatsapp... we also went to the airport around 8 am. We waited till 10.30 am before seeing someone from Kenya Airways. they were surprised that Akwa Palace refused us. Obviously it was too late for the Rwandair flight that could have bring us to Nairobi.

Around 1.30 pm we finally got a rebooking proposition (yep, we waited from 8 am to 1.30 pm in a non AC' airport). And remember, I did not sleep all night before that.

The proposition is a 21hours journey (3 flights) with Ethiopian Airline. In economic class, with refund (which I have to claim for! and perhaps you will refund within 21 to 30 days...). I asked to be booked in first class : refused. I asked to Ethipian to pay for the upgrade : too late!

Boarding tome : 1.20 pm. It s 2.30 pm and we are still waiting without any explanation of course.

So, guys, flying with Kenya Airways and you get :

- Degraded from sky priority to economic.
- Lost hotel reservations in Nairobi and Zanzibar.
- Lost 2 tours reservations in Zanzibar.
- Loosing time to make the claim.
- Loosing at least 2.5 days of Holiday.

IS THIS WHAT YOU CALL PREMIER WORLD ?

Title:
My wife and myself flew from Nairobi to Zanzibar after having finished a 2 weeks Safari in Kenya. The entire trip including Zanzibar stay of was pre-booked and paid for about a year ago, most of it, as the accommodations, non-refundable. Hence I boosted my travel insurance, included all “ifs” and bumped it to 15k USD, just in case.

However, all went very well except for one issue, and that was with Kenya Airways. The ticket to Zanzibar on Sept 18th with flight KQ 494 was booked and paid 9 months in advance, flight departure 18:20.
Long story short: that flight was cancelled for operational reasons as Kenya Airways said, the notification likely ended up in the SPAM as I never got it. The airline did not send out any SMS (that would come with a failure of delivery if not received) despite my number on record and permission to contact via phone. Hence I noticed the change 1 day in advance when checking the flight. More so, Kenya Airways had changed our booking to a flight next morning, despite an evening option available. Now, it’s not hard to guess that this would cause issues because barely any traveler, business or personal, does NOT have a booked agenda in post-Corona times. The other evening flight option however was fully booked by the time the problem was noticed as it turned out. Result: a lost expensive overnight stay in Stone town, and a dinner with friends.
Once arrived at the Airport on the original departure day, the customer service agent of Kenya Airways at the airport was extremely arrogant and very commanding as if the entire issue was our fault. Absolute exceptionally bad experience here on top of our interrupted vacation. While we did receive an voucher for overnight stay in Nairobi, the entire action and communication around it was not acceptable. I have Senator Status with LH and do fly quite a bit. Things go wrong and did so for me too, but this attitude of an Airline employee was new to us.

Kenya Airline declines responsibility despite the change for operational reasons and keeps sending me articles of the policy to say they don’t pay. Due to pre-booking, no refund for the lost stay by the hotel in Stone town or my travel agency and despite all bells and whistles in my travel insurance: if it is not force majeure but due the Airline's changes, the Airline is responsible. No travel insurance would apparently ever pay here.

So to all travelers: pay attention here, there is many other airlines I know with a lot better customer service and much more flexible policies when it comes down to issue. Everyone can do great when there is no problem, the value of an Airline shows when problems come up. The entire behavior of Kenya Airlines and in particular the customer service agent on top of all the hassle anyway is just totally unacceptable. This was the first and for sure last time. At least in and around Kenya and Tanzania try Precision Air as an alternative. As I still believe the originator of the problem will have to bear the consequences, I will continue and pursue ways to get my refund.
qwuub: When it comes to problems, the "real service" and quality shows

Title:
Used Kenya Airways for a three stop journey from Heathrow to Amsterdam, the first leg of the journey was with KLM with no problems. The next leg was from Amsterdam to Nairobi followed by an onward leg to Dar Es Salaam. We were assured on more than one occasion that our luggage would go straight through from Heathrow to Dar Es Salaam. on arrival we went to collect our luggage only to be told it was still in Nairobi, eventually we managed to speak to a manager over the phone who told us our luggage would be sent out on the next plane and assured us it would be sent to our hotel which it did at 21:30, during that time we spent the day in our hotel room in the clothes we had been in since leaving home.
We left Dar Es Salaam early next morning for our safari holiday.
Holiday over and at Dar Es Salaam airport for our return flights this time to Nairobi then straight through to Heathrow. The Business class lounge was clean and well run, a chap by the name of Dough is worth a mention he was polite, helpful and did everything to ensure we were looked after.
The leg from Dar Es Salaam to Nairobi was quite short and went without a hitch.

The lounge in Nairobi was extremely poor, the food was low standard and running out , one passenger asked if there was more food coming and was shouted at saying "it's coming man" , I think the passenger was in shock As so was I, he wished me good luck and walked off.
Lounge tables were left uncleaned and dirty crockery from other passengers not cleared.
While in the lounge I took a shower to freshen up, the towel given to me was worn out and covered in holes and the water didn't regulate so I had a cold shower.
We boarded our aircraft for our final leg to the UK, not long after takeoff we were given breakfast, a little better than what you would expect in economy but not good enough for business class, this was really the last time we saw a stewardess until lunch which was no better, as they drew the curtains and stayed behind them, as we were just behind the bulk head, I did notice a stewardess through the curtain flossing her teeth.
Not once did anyone come around and offer water or a drink even though it was a long journey.
The toilets were not kept cleaned and the floors wet, there were also passengers coming through the business class from economy to use the toilets without being stopped, I don't want to sound snobby but this is what we pay a lot extra for.
The entertainment was also poor, no games and the films and programmes very old.
We have travelled on several business class airlines and none as bad as this, not even a smile from the disinterested staff.

Title:

The return flight from Nairobi had a far superior meal service on the other hand. Seats are in 2-2-2 configuration which provides a huge amount of space. In Nairobi we transferred to a Precision Air flight down to Kilimanjaro. The experience was seamless and we even had time to visit the Pride Lounge which had an excellent breakfast on offer. Ground crew in Nairobi were professional and friendly and made one feel valued. Pity I can’t say the same about the KLM boarding agents in Amsterdam.

All in all, KQ provides good value for money.

Title:
The experience from start to finish was poor. Our routing was Cape Town / Nairobi / Zanzibar and then Zanzibar / Nairobi / Johannesburg / Cape Town. We checked in the night before our flight to Zanzibar and appeared fine. Fortunately, our travel agent was on the ball and checked the flights in the morning and saw that they had changed the flight to Nairobi and we were now going to miss the connection on to Zanzibar. The airline wasn't very helpful but our agent managed to get us on to a Precision Air flight from Nairobi to Zanzibar. There was no message from Kenya airways - apology - change - comment - nothing.

It meant a whole day in Nairobi instead of a few hours but we made the most of it.

Then when we arrived in Zanzibar, they had lost two of the six bags that we had checked in. In addition, the Kenya Airways check-in in Cape Town had mixed up all of our bags and luggage tags so we had to decipher which bags were lost by deduction. Despite the lady being quite sweet at check-in this was just unprofessional

We took the approach of chasing Kenya Airways, Precision Air (the last leg), the land agent on Zanzibar (Africa Stay) and ZAT the airport management company in Zanzibar. Of all of those Kenya Airways was the most backward.

Kenya Airways had both a web and WhatsApp channel for logging support issues and both were equally useless and there was no coordination between either. Neither gave us any useful information or made any positive contribution to us finding our bags.

Eventually Africa Stay and Precision each found and delivered a bag :-) and we got them on Monday after arriving Friday. Kenya Air sent me a message asking me for feedback on their support despite not knowing that the bags had been delivered to us. This was funny.

Again on our return, we checked in the night before and all was well. At the airport, they handed us boarding passes for the two flights Zanzibar - Nairobi and Nairobi - Johannesburg without saying any word about changes. We happened to check the boarding pass for the gate in Nairobi and my wife noticed that the time on the flight to Jhb was two hours later than scheduled (and on our original boarding passes that we had printed the night before). Lastly, every single Kenya Airways flight on the trip left late i.e. even later than the adjusted late time that they had already moved it on the schedule.

Clearly, they have very immature processes for operating both their flight schedule and their operations. You may get lucky but based on their 100% failure rate with our flights and luggage I would bet against it.

Title:
It was our 1st family holiday, no holiday for us for the last 3 years due to covid and a newborn. 2022 was the year for us to fly.
Me frantically trying to find tickets that would fit our budget but also thinking about Emirates and Qatar standards, Kenya Airways was last in the list even though they had a direct flight and especially reading recent reviews i was like "No! not flying our national carrier"

Alas as budget was the main concern i closed my eyes and booked with KQ with a tear in my eye and said to myself "as long as we reach safe"
Day arrived, 2 year old excited running all around the airport busy trying to hold her in the queue to check in. 1st sign of things were going to be ok is the staff at the KQ desk in LHR let us jump the queue, checked in quick and also kindly tagged our pram and told us we can have it up until boarding and can have it once we arrive.

We left on time.

Fast forward to mid flight, the crew were kind, and served and attended to passengers with smiles on their faces and seem to understand a crying baby. offered us food first (we'll come back to the food later).
Lights off in the cabin baby still awake, I decided to take her to the back where the crew was and just stand there and keep her occupied. The crew were singing to her offered juice and empty plastic glasses to play with. That made the flight seem to go very quick and got her tired enough to sleep, managed to get 2 hours of sleep and landing time seemed to reach quick.

When we reached the opened airplane door the cold Nairobi breeze greeting us, guess what, our pram was on the tarmac waiting for us to pick it up and stroll towards baggage reclaim and immigration no carrying, "WOW!" i said to my wife, "so far so good. now our bags"
Cleared immigration and we reached baggage carousel already rolling and bags on their way, 10 mins later our bags arrive, 1,2,3,4,5 bags. yup all of them here safe and sound :)
As we get the bags on the trolley we here a cheerful "hello!" it was on of the cabin crew who kept our baby occupied in the plane. He asked if we were ok and if we needed any help but we were fine, he waved and wished us a good holiday.

Our holiday went great and now we are back and the flight back was equally amazing just sad we were coming back.

I felt KQ deserved a good review after being bombarded with negative reviews which I truly understand and I consider myself lucky, just credit when its due.

Hopefully KQ stays afloat and managed with care and love and looking after the employees as i feel its still truly the "Pride of Africa"

My only criticism will be the inflight meal, no sukuma banaaaa lol

I would think it would be common sense that an email in the middle of the night 8 hours prior to the new proposed flight time (for a now 7:30am flight) is insufficient notice. Even after speaking to multiple different Kenya Airways employees, I was never given a reason for the flight time change (just "operations"). Ultimately we were rebooked for a flight late that day, but this was an indirect flight through Dubai, which didn't leave until 5:10pm and involved >16 hours of travel instead of what was supposed to be a 4 hour and 20 minute flight. Because of this, we were unable to check in for our hotel that we had paid for the night of our arrival and instead arrived the next morning, exhausted, having been traveling all night and transferring in Dubai in the middle of the night. To boot, the behavior of the passengers on the plane from Nairobi to Dubai was absurd. People were constantly standing up on the plane and blocking the aisle even after being asked to sit down by flight attendants. Kids were running around unrestrained and flight attendants had to ask over the intercom for parents to restrain their children multiple times. In the row in front of me someone was watching a movie on a tablet with nonstop gunfire with the volume on max and he was not using headphones. Bottom line, if you can avoid it, do NOT fly on Kenya Airways. You will absolutely regret it. Title: Monrovia to Kigali through Accra and Nairobi 19-20 May 2022. The 2 aircrafts were both B737-800s in very good condition. I had to change my departure dates and it took me only 10 Minutes online - and was even free as it was a “Business Light” ticket. All flights were on time. Checked in online. Monrovia Airport is full of hustlers pretending to be from the airline but want tips and they are annoying, the airline should chase them away. Kenya Airways (KQ) uses a third party lounge in Monrovia which is small but good with courteous, proactive attendants. No champagne, but plenty of drinks and liquor. The local Club beer is good. Embarking easy, fast, not a single crosscheck from lounge to seat – what a pleasure. Onboard, welcome drinks were served. The seats were huge and well bolstered, reclining, new, and very comfortable. Could sleep. IFE or WiFi was only working on the last leg. No printed menus were given out, but the FAs asked each individual on food choices. My pre-ordered special sea food meals were all different, delicious, and served without reminders. Business Class was full after Accra, but I did neither feel cramped nor stuffy. FAs, all Kenyans, were good and caring – though maybe not world class. In NBO the Pride lounge did the job for me during the 12 hours’ layover. The last stretch to Kigali was with IFE onboard, champagne, and my beloved seafood hot meal, which KQ still offers (even in economy) in contrast to Qatar and Emirates who have stopped this service at is it not qualifying as “dietary reasons” to order. Luggage delivered quickly and in good order. Good value for money – will fly with them again.

Title:
Flew Kigali to Monrovia over Nairobi and Accra on 8-9 May 2022. Flights on time. Checked in online worked well and got my BPs in airport swiftly. No luggage issues. Recognised as Skyteam elite. KQ staff came to me in lounge and, without request, carried my hand-luggage for me from lounge to the aircraft. No waiting time nor queues anywhere on the trip despite the flights were full or almost full. KQ delivers and have rarely let me down over the years.

Pearl Lounge in Kigali delivers but suffers from deprived views of airport runways.

First flight was on an Embraer 190 which is a lovely, roomy aircraft. Onboard, they allowed me to shift to an exit row as my original seat was mistakingly occupied by another person. The seat now offered was very nice - it would have costed me 50 USD if booked online. Drinks were generously provided. Appreciate KQ often have the Happy Hour concept where a request for a single drink most often triggers serving two. The wine in mini-bottles was acceptable, a South African “Stonedale”. I had requested seafood meal and I got it: it was a cold, tasty salmon sandwich. FAs were kind and effective. No IFE nor WiFi but on a 90 minutes flight its not an issue.

Transit in Nairobi Airport smooth and quick. It took me only 15 Minutes to reach the KQ Pride Lounge. I love this lounge, roomy and curvy designs with lots of nice sections. Had a god nights’ sleep after acquainting myself with a Niederburg rose-wine which superseded an alternative, Italian sparkling wine

The next flights from Nairobi to Monrovia via Accra were on their B737-800. Despite the flight was completely full (all seats taken in both classes!) the staff manage to care passengers well. No power outlet nor monitors, only WiFi and use of personal devices were possible. Special meal rendered to perfection. I also tried other dishes as I was offered. Drinks provided generously, again Happy Hour (order 1 get 2) occurred at least once. Slight delay as the stop-over in Accra took longer time as a lot of passengers disembarked before cleaning and loads of new passengers came on board – again the flight was full. Luggage in Monrovia came out quickly. Nicely done, Kenya Airways. Can recommend.

Title:
By the multiple bad reviews I already knew Kenya Airways was not a great airline. However, my multiple experiences with this airline have been even worse than expected.

In brief, the most serious problem stems from the customer service if you live in the USA. When you call, you wait a long time. Then, it is very rare that the person you talk to has the authority/ability/training to do anything you are requesting. Oftentimes, they say a supervisor will call you back. Trust me, they never will!

When you attempt to send emails to guest support or customer service there is a small probability you will ever hear back from them. I'm not confident they even look at the emails.

In one experience on a flight they double booked/double charged me, I made no less than 30 phone calls and sent no less than 25 emails. The result? Absolutely nothing!

Naturally, I would recommend avoiding this airline altogether. However, due to limited flight options in Africa, many times you have no choice in the matter.

Here a five tips:
1. If possible, always pick a European airline when coming into the Continent; never choose Kenya Airways unless it is the last option.
2. While in Africa, recognize that Kenya Airways is actually better than many of the other African airlines. This is hard to believe, but true. Here are the airlines in Africa that are better if you have the option: RwandAir, Ethiopian Airlines, and South African Airways.
3. If you a book a ticket for Kenya Airways, always do so on a 3rd party site (American Express, Expedia, etc.). Even though this sounds counterintuitive, there are oftentimes significant problems with the Kenya Airways payment website. In fact, I once had a situation where I bought a ticket on Kenya Airways website, and then discovered additional charges on my credit card saying, "Kenya Airways." It turned out that a scam artist was stealing information from Kenya Airways and actually using the name, "Kenya Airways." Obviously, this is a real problem!
4. If you have a problem and need to make a change or seek a refund, don't waste much time on the matter. If they offer you a refund with a 40% cancellation fee, take it immediately (even if it makes no sense and isn't fair)! Take whatever you can get but be prepared to get nothing. Sorry, but this is just the way it is.
5. Be thankful if your flight actually flies on the day scheduled. And. as always, be grateful that you arrive safely!

So why do I offer 2 stars instead of a 1 star in my rating? Because I can at least get Sky Team points when using Kenya Airways. Oh, by the way, getting the points will also be difficult!

Title:
Given the many not-so-great reviews about Kenya Airways, I went into this flight with relatively low expectations. However, I found almost none of the negative reviews to be true.

First off the check in process online and in person was easier than my experience with even some US airlines. I was able to check in online and then at the check in counter at JFK (where there was absolutely no line) the attendant was able to "upgrade" my wife and I to an exit row for no additional charge (whereas on the website this was an additional fee. My one complaint about the seat selection process is that It's pretty unclear what paying more for a seat really gets you. Either way, i'd recommend doing it at the counter. Also - I used their whatsapp number to try and attempt to upgrade to business class and was communicating with a real person!

The flight itself was fairly empty, perhaps 60% to capacity. Overall I thought the plane was very spacious, clean and the service was excellent. They were cleaning the bathrooms frequently and refilling drinks without even asking. Overall the food was fine... nothing to go crazy about, but it was pretty much what you'd expect with economy airline food (chicken or pasta).

I will say, as many of the other reviews have noted, the entertainment system was pretty sub par. They had a few great movies, and not the most intuitive UI. I did also find it bizarre there wasn't even an option for wifi.. it's slightly old school, just download stuff in advance! The seat itself also didn't have the best lumbar support, I used the pillow they gave you for added support and brought a head pillow.

Our final destination was JRO with a 3 hour layover in Nairobi. Overall our journey was about 16 ish hours, FAR LESS than some of the other options with Qatar, KLM etc. which are all great airlines, but I do value time (and saving money), so I thought this was a great overall option for someone going on Safari in Kenya and/or Tanzania. I'd do it again for sure.

Not a knock on Kenya Airways, but the NBO airport is pretty poor, i'd recommend going to the lounge if your credit card or status gives you lounge access. We paid $40 a piece to sit in there for 2.5 hours which was fine, but not one of the better lounges I have seen.

Title: Let me preface this review by stating that I am not an overly critical reviewer, feel free to check my other reviews. With that out of the way let's begin.       If you live in the USA, you are probably planning your once in a lifetime safari vacation via Kenya Airways direct flight from JFK to Nairobi, and you have noticed the cheap price. You're probably thinking "how bad can it be?". Let me tell you.      Our adventure started two years ago as we planned our trip to Uganda and Kenya.  We were to fly to Nairobi from JFK, then transfer to Entebee. After our Uganda safari we would fly back to Nairobi and do a short Kenya safari before flying home. Like most travellers, COVID ruined our 2020 plans. Kenya Airways offered vouchers, again like most airlines. Now the fun began. There website does not show a US phone number, but I found one and used it, but most of the time they either didn't pick up or you were put on hold until you had to give up and get on with your life. The website did have a online chat with a type to an agent option. The chat would start with KA writing you are in third position approximate wait 15 minutes, after an hour you would be in first position and get a message "all our agents are busy please try later. At times I even emailed guest services, after a few days I sometimes got a response. At one point I gave in and phoned the Nairobi office, there I got a response and $30 phone bill. Eventually I got everything in place, including what the call premium economy. Premium economy cost  a $150 dollars a seat extra and got you the front row of economy with no one in the middle seat of there 3-3-3 set up. On the flight to Nairobi I asked if they had any available business class left, they did and at a reasonable price I upgraded. Nobody can screw up business class, so we had a nice flight to Nairobi. My only complaint, and slight is that the entertainment package was pretty bad. Their showcase movies was stuff I saw  six months or a year ago on HBO.        Now for the flight home. We arrived at the airport 3.5 hours early, after all things get slow because of COVID precautions. KA booked their flights to New York and Paris fifteen minutes apart. As a result you had around 700 people checking in at four check-in desks. Not exactly a safe way to check people in at this time. When we got to the check-in desk, I asked if they had anything available in business and was told it was a completely sold out.  My wife and I at least were comforted with the fact we would get the front row of economy with the middle seat empty.. When we got on the plane, we approached our seats and guess what: the middle seats had people in them.  We took our narrow hard seats, that were better than Frontier airlines seats, but nowhere as good as a Southwest Airlines seat. From there we started our 14 hour flight home, where we were served horrible food (even by airlines standards), with the old fashioned two prong earphones in which you ad to install the pads on the earphones by yourself. The little amenities you usually find on long haul flights like a small personal care kit were available only in business class. The only fortunate part of the flight is that it took off at midnight, so we somehow slept through half the torture.       So let me sum up. You are probably looking forward to a trip of a lifetime, and it's one pretty penny. Pay a little extra and find another airline. If your safari doesn't start in Kenya, you are going to transfer anyway so don't be lured by the direct flight. If you don't heed my advice and have the same type of trip that I and other reviewers speak of, you can't say you weren't warned.

Title:
Flights from Kilimanjaro to Dubai via Nairobi (Kenya Airways)

The main question is why Kenya Airways is selling tickets to customers for flights that they are no longer operating? This is misleading and deceitful!

Initial flights booked online with Kenya Airways on 18/10/2020 by credit card

Flights Details:
Kilimanjaro to Nairobi Flight KQ427 19th December
Nairobi to Dubai Flight KQ304 19th December
Dubai to Nairobi Flight KQ305 4th January
Nairobi to Kilimanjaro Flight KQ0426 4th January

On the 7/12/2020, I filled in an online support to seek confirmation that the flights would go ahead and I received an automated response to confirm that the flights would still go ahead, which was untruthful on the part of Kenya Airways.

On the 15th December, we received an email from Kenya Airways Arusha Office to inform us that Flight KQ427 from Kilimanjaro to Nairobi on 19th December had been cancelled and that we were going to be redirected via Dar Es Salam and had to take Flight PW0431 with Precision Air from Kilimanjaro to Dar Es Salam. She sent us new tickets by email but for some reason, issued new tickets with different Booking Reference Numbers.

Flight details:
Kilimanjaro to Dar Es Salam Flight PW0431 19th December
Dar Es Salam to Nairobi Flight KQ0485 19th December
Nairobi to Dubai Flight KQ304 19th December

Dubai to Nairobi Flight KQ305 4th January
Nairobi to Kilimanjaro Flight KQ0426 4th January

On the 18th December, one day before our journey, we received an automated email to inform us that Flight KQ 304 from Nairobi to Dubai on the 19th December had been cancelled and that we were rebooked onto Flight KQ 304DE on 20th December at 6:05 instead but we received no updated tickets. We were then sent an automated email message that my wife was now booked onto an Emirates flight EK 722 that evening but no information about my son or me. I attempted to seek help on the online via the Kenya Airways site but nobody replied to us to check if we had all been booked on to the Emirates flight but nobody replied. New tickets were not emailed to us either, so we were left confused as to which flights we were now supposed to take from Nairobi to Dubai.

Our Experience on the 19th December 2020 - Outward Journey:

At Check-in for Precision Air Flight, we were informed by the check-in member of staff that my wife's flight ticket had been exchanged but that they had not received the new ticket from Kenya Airways on their system, so she could not fly. Precision Air staff manged to make contact with Kenya Airways and it was eventually sorted.

In Dar Es Salam, we managed to speak to a member of staff at the Kenya Airways sales office at Terminal 3 to try to confirm our flights from Nairobi to Dubai and that we were all still booked on the same flight as a family. She was very unhelpful and said that she could not help us, despite the fact we were now booked on different flights. She said that we had to proceed on the next leg of our journey to Nairobi and seek help at the transfer desk in Nairobi.

On arrival in Nairobi, we proceeded to the transfer desk and the member of staff was helpful. She removed my wife from the Emirates flight and rebooked my wife back to the morning flight, so that we could travel together as a family. The member of staff was very helpful, organised us a transit visa and a hotel room for a few hours before the morning flight to Dubai. We simply do not understand why my wife's flight was changed and not my son and mine without even asking us, informing us properly or even sending us any updated tickets?
The morning flight from Nairobi to Dubai was a very pleasant flight!

On the 25th December, we finally received a Guest Support Response from Faith Mutuku from Kenya Airways regarding our outward journey but by that time, we had arrived in Dubai.

Title:
We flew from JFK to NBO just before the pandemic was declared. This was the first leg of a journey to Seychelles (SEZ). We found the cabin crew on this flight to be excellent, attentive, and really friendly. I had read reports about the service and staff being patchy on this route with travelers left for hours without refreshments or with unfriendly staff but it seemed that the cabin staff were up and down the aisles very frequently and always had a smile on their faces .... something that must be tough during these times. We told them how pleased we were at the end of the flight and they seemed genuinely surprised to get the positive feedback. We passed this on to the airline via their website but have received no response as yet.

Check in at JFK was easy, but probably atypical due to the reduced number of flyers in early March this year. The same could be said for the boarding process.

The plane itself was new, a lovely 787 with mood lighting and big windows. The legroom was reasonable (not cramped but not luxurious). Overall it was comfortable for such a long journey. The food on the outbound journey was actually really good, way better than we expected, and our son' child's meal was also better than typical kids meals.

The biggest negative on our outbound journey was the entertainment system. There were very few recent movies and the choice was extremely limited. Take your tablet or phone and download some eBooks, movies or other entertainment to it. if you are expecting to use the system on the plane to keep you occupied for 14 hours you will be disappointed.

If I was rating the airline based on this flight I would actually give this flight 4 or even 5 stars as it was enjoyable but external factors are influencing that rating :

- Our return journey from Seychelles was delayed overnight by 14 hours and we had to fight to get accommodation. Due to this delay, and the Kenyan government ban on entry for foreigners due to COVID-19, it also meant our mini KQ Safari booked through the airline had to be cancelled. This is all very understandable and we have no issue with any of that. We cancelled this over email with the safari division while in the Seychelles and assumed there would be no issue.

However, despite meeting 3 of the criteria needed for refund I am now going through a VISA charge-back process to recover this fee. First they say to talk to travel agent (when we booked the safari directly through them on a different credit card number) and then they say its valid for a year and they do not refund services .. despite having a clear statement on their website that a refund can be done if you fit 1 of the 3 criteria - 1. contact the email provided within 24 hours of the safari to cancel (we did it 6 days before), 2. Have a flight cancellation or delay (we were cancelled and put on a flight 14 hours later), and 3. Being denied entry to the country (the government were denying foreign nationals even with a visa - which we had).

We want to go back to the Seychelles when all this is over but sadly I fear it will need to be with another airline, despite the stellar service of the staff on KQ003 on the day we flew.

Title:
We travelled from Mumbai to Nairobi by KQ 205 on 23 Jan 2020 as part of 25 persons travelling together. Individual bookings were made by us. Apart from people having been in major positions in the Corporate world, we had a former Director from a major airline travelling with us.

The baggage for none of us arrived in Nairobi , we travelled to Amboseli the same day. The baggage next day(24 Jan 2020) was delivered in Nairobi in the office of our travel agent in the morning. Where we requested them to send it to Amboseli and paid for it.





The counter staff(girl) was of no help and categorically said that the airline had no system of compensating. They could only talk about any compensation after 24 hrs of delay. We arrived Nairobi on on the morning of 23 Jan 2020, with scheduled arrival time of 1020 hrs. We finally received the baggage in Amboseli at 1600 hrs on 24 Jan 2020, that also with our initiative. Inspite of our best efforts the Duty Manager was not contactable at the Airport and even later. Our numbers were taken and no one even contacted us. Our Office was in touch with Kenya Airways in Delhi, who were the only ones able to tell us about loading of the baggage in the next flight to Nairobi from Mumbai.



Although when we lodged a complaint regarding the delayed baggage, were told that same would be delivered to our hotel the next morning and would be sent by the early morning flight.

At no stage did we receive any compensation, apart from being put to inconvenience.



We were travelling in Kenya in different places and started back on 29 Jan 2020 by KQ 204 and reached Mumbai on 30 Jan 2020. The staff at the airport in Nairobi had no answers for the delayed baggage compensation.



On flight experience:-



My wife was given seat no 15B on the flight KQ 205 to Nairobi. The seat had no button and could not recline. She called the Air Hostess to tell her that it was uncomfortable, due to her back needed a reclining seat and in case another seat could be given, she came back to say that the flight was full and she would not be in a position to help. She requested for the Flight supervisor, who came, he should be really commended for his non friendly and unprofessional attitude. An experienced and mature man, who had answers to everything, how things could not be done. He was kind enough to give lectures on advantages of not using a reclining seat, a straight seat was good for the back. We had four super specialist Doctors travelling with us, since we were on Kenya Airways flight had to take his advise.She even requested him stating that we have 25 persons travelling on board booked by our company and were ready to pay for the seat in Business Class, since there were seats vacant in the Business Class. He had a prompt reply to say that there was no provision to help her, she could get down in Nairobi and write a mail to Kenya Airways , they would revert and help her out. So much for inflight service and conduct of flight supervisor.



It did not end there. Before boarding the return flight KQ 204 on 29 Jan 2019,told the customer relations at the Airport to check that the seat should be reclining or put a remark that the seat should be fine,since the seat number was the same as 15B. Usual answer to say that they had no system of doing that. This time the seat had the button, but could not be reclined. This apart there was a very inhuman experience, my wife suddenly fell sick and collapsed on the seat. I jumped out of my seat to take help of the Doctor friends sitting two seats away. I told the Air Hostess that the Doctor is going to attend to her she is not well. She was very curt to tell me that I was coming on her way for them to serve others, we had also not taken our meals. Imagine the plight of a sick passenger and the attitude of the crew, if we did not have Doctor friends travelling wth us. Doctors reacted fast and gave her medicine and she slowly started reviving. Meanwhile I called the flight supervisor , Mr Raymond, who at least understood and got the box of medicines and the Doctor was comfortable and said that necessary injections could be given if required, since these were available on board. The Air Hostess did come back and apologise, obviously from the inputs she must have received. Only thing I told her was that even today, I go out of the way to help any accident victim, even on the road. He should do the same on the flight,



I had to personally bear the brunt from everyone, since my company decided to take 25 persons on a tour of Kenya(4 in Business Class and 21 in Economy)and I decided to travel with them, something that I do not do. In this case all were friends and known to me.



I have personally flown enough and have been in the travel business for over 30 years, regrettably it was a nightmare to have taken these flights.



When I meet people anywhere I always tell people that have never had a bad experience and people have always been wonderful. I would not call this a bad experience, anywhere in the world or any airline, at least people are humane. It was totally amiss here.

Kenya is a wondeful country but would advise no one to fly Kenya Airways.

As advised by Kenya Airways office lodged an online complaint on 05/02/20, with a resolution date of 08/02/20 it 14/02/20 and still waiting to hear from them.

Title: Flew Bangkok-Johannesburg over Nairobi on 5th February 2020. Both flights on newer B787-8 aircrafts. Check-in and luggage handling went smoothly, but had to fight a bit with ground staff to get all my BPs issued on spot. Booking handling online works well. Their AF-KLM lounge offered in Bangkok is poor (like Thai Airways lounges) but their Pride lounge in Nairobi is good and spacious. Hardware on Kenya Airways is good and they are good on ground to tackle even complicated issues. The FAs are also good, plenty, observant. They are mainly Kenyans which does not help Chinese nor Thai passengers much. The very weak point of KQ is the food. Business class does not provide food any better than their Economy class and is plain, without vision, looking shabby. Competing airlines like Ethiopian, Turkish, South African, and Egypt serves much better and inspiring food in their economy class. Steel cutlery and table preparation nice. But that’s it. Dinner from BKK was a cold shabby dish with chopped salad and 3 ridiculous small pieces of sliced meatballs. Breakfast offered was inedible continental or fried rice. Very poor offerings. No meat, no cocktails, no cheeses, no icecream, no smoothies, chocolates, no fruits (watermelon does not count). Extremely poor catering, a disgrace for the airline. Beverages are shamefully very sparse, only 2 juices (apple or orange) are offered. Wines are only passable. Beers are cheap, waterish industrial stuff: 2 brands, Tusker and Heineken – not providing any alternatives to each other. No souvenir, no pyjamas, no luxury feelings at all. No lobster, no seafood, no caviar, no mutton, goat, pork, no beef, no chicken (maybe inside the breakfast sausage).  FA staff admitted that economy class had the same catering as business though of course presented simpler. 1st flight on time, 2nd departed 1 hour late. Miles given quickly to Flying Blue. I will go again when the price is right. Lower expectation to food to zero and eat well at home or in lounge. Then it can be fairly good value for money when prices are promoted.

Title:
I was scheduled to leave Bangui for Nairobi and then spend a night in Nairobi before flying to Paris. As indicated by Kenya airways representatives at the airport, the flight from Bangui was cancelled due to technical reason.

The representatives at the airport were uninformed and unable to provide basic information concerning follow-on flights and any compensation due to inconveniences caused by the cancellation (for instance hotel room and any follow-on reservation already reserved in Nairobi and at the final destination). We were told to comeback at the airport the following day at 1500 to all get on the next flight. We were also told that if any earlier flight would be available, that we would be contacted by phone.

That evening I contacted by phone Kenya Airways and was told that I was in fact already scheduled to leave the next day early in the morning and not at 1500 (as confirmed by their representative). The KQ representative never called me to inform me that I should present myself earlier. Had I not dealt with this by myself, I would have missed my re-routing flight.

With the flight cancellation:
- I arrived to my final destination over 20 hours late.
-I had to wait 12 hours in Douala for my connecting flight (where Kenya airways did not even provide me with a 10$ voucher or something to recognize the long layover) - I did not benefit from any of the service provided by Kenya airways representatives in Bangui, as again, they provided me initially with inaccurate information and then were totally absent in following-up with an update.

When I did a compensation claim for this travel, Kenya airways inform me that they could only issue me a 100$ voucher that can only be used to travel with them again, or pay for their lounge or excess luggage (which is clearly what I will avoid doing in the future). This voucher is not going to even cover the basic cost of my delay (loss hotel reservation, money spent at the airport for the 12 hours layover etc).

Highly disappointed in the customer service of this company. If you fly with them make sure you have great insurance (they themselves asked me to contact my individual travel insurer for recompense as they would not do anything). Avoid altogether.

Title:
I've been flying KQ to Nairobi for business since 2015. First started with them after I couldn't deal anymore with Ethiopian Airlines' normal 2 am arrival time in Nairobi (getting people to come and pick you up in the pre-Uber days always involved more effort than I could deploy). I started with them with much trepidation initially, but 4 years down the line, I must say that they have done very well, so far.

Flight attendants are of variable quality, some make it seem as if they would rather be elsewhere; some are friendly and professional. Pilots are generally good - I travel around in Europe fairly frequently and would say KQ pilots measure up to what I've experienced there. One major gripe is the old -looking planes and poor in-flight entertainment options - only flown an newish KQ plane once when they put a Dreamliner on the Lagos-Nairobi route. Food is of variable quality per flight, but again as far as I am concerned all airline food is generally lousy. Taking another KQ flight in February - I understand the Kenyan government is taking the airline over again next year - so will watch the airline a while after February to see how its fortunes develop.

Title:
When booking our flight we paid a large amount extra to ensure extra leg room as my partner is quite tall so finds long flights very uncomfortable in standard seats. We were sat in front of a bulkhead which was fine, but we then found that as the lady in thr seat next to us had a small baby she would need the cot that KA provide. These hang on the bulkhead. At this point the member of crew asked us if we would be using our in flight entertainment while flying because once the cot is in place the screen cannot be put up. We said we did want it, it was an 8 hour flight so entertainment was needed! Once the screen was up we found ourselves to be completely trapped in our seats. There was no way to get out without either taking down the entire cot or asking the lady next to us to move so we could clamber over the seats (which we didnt like to do as she was travelling alone and the situation was not at all her fault). To summarise, we had the choice of being bored for the flight but being able to get to the toilet, or to watch films and be stuck in our seats.
The health implications of not being able to freely move are obvious, as is the safety concern should there be an emergency evacuation with no time to remove the cot etc! This situation would have been annoying at the standard price but having paid significantly more, we were no better off than in a standard seat.

We also found the entertainment system control to be damaged in one of our seats.

Once home we tried to contact KA through the recommended channels regarding the matter. We followed this up with a further email asking for someone to get back to us. To date, 7 weeks since we flew, no response has been recieved.

Title:
Is this the worst airline in the world or at least the worst in Africa? It depends on the assessment criteria of course but after a recent experience in Sierra Leone flying to Accra in Ghana I'd say it well deserves the title.
First let me confirm that it was equipment failure [the left engine] that stopped the flight and with that I have no problem at all - I'd rather be alive and late than dead in the air on time. So for safety they get a big tick; though conversations among other stranded passengers might suggest that these problems occur so frequently for KQ as to question the thoroughness of Kenya Airways maintenance schedules.
It is not the ordinary on time scheduled performance by which an airline should be judged but rather how they handle a problem or crisis. I could provide chapter and verse, if this review space allowed for such specifics, as to how badly they performed - no customer care, almost non existent communication, no systematic response, no evidence of organization and process - it was chaos from the outset. Such might, at a very long stretch be excusable in the crisis of the initial moment, but the chaos persisted all through the next day when they'd had overnight and 24 hours to get things sorted [and i don't mean in repairing the plane - i mean in taking care of their customers].
Constantly they misled, prevaricated, offered contradictory advice and information, made promises they couldn't possibly have managed, withheld information, undertook to contact everyone the next day by a particular time and no contact at that time or ever was received, botched arrangements for overnight accommodation and transport to and from ..... the list of systemic failures is endless.
Everything that happened was avoidable - we suffered the consequences of 'just in time thinking' - it is obvious that Kenya Airways have no plans or systems in place for such a predictable emergency, or if they do then they don't know how to implement them. We were assured from the outset that they were in touch with head office in Nairobi so one can only assume that the incompetence displayed reaches to the very top of the organization.
By now the reader may be thinking 'well you get what you pay for'. And pay I certainly did - this was a premier world ticket [their business class] and it cost for the 2 hour flight about 4 times what a similar length flight on any one of 6 major airlines in Europe would cost. [Yes the legroom and food and cleanliness on Board were fine but they pale into insignificance besides the demonstrated witless response to a problem]
Most alarmingly chaos prevailed even when we finally got on a flight 28 hours later - I heard passengers being told by the cabin crew and Pursar as they came on board to just sit anywhere as the boarding passes for the flight didn't match. I am not sure what the passenger manifest signed off by KQ for that flight represented but it would seem not to have borne much connection to the human contents of the flight.
You might have perhaps expected this review to end by advising that there was some follow up from the company, some check that things had got sorted, perhaps an apology, because their PR spiel says that we are valued customers and they want us to fly with them again - and they do know our names and our contact details after all. Not a word, not a call, not a text message, not an email, not a general tweet - just silence!
Kenya Airways call themselves the "Pride of Africa" - if I was an African Nation I would be insisting they stop bringing the name of Africa into disrepute.
So my advice - Avoid if you can and if you can't expect the worst and you won't be disappointed.

Title:
I was booked on Kenya airways when I used last-minute.com to book my flights to Nairobi. The first 2 legs were via air France then the final leg to Nairobi was Kenya airways. The flight from Amsterdam to Nairobi was on time thankfully but the plane, considering it's not that old, was tired and dated. The service wasn't great. You won't receive the offer of a drink unless it's meal time and no snacks are provided. The food wasn't great, beef or chicken curry with rice for the hot meal and a stale croissant and piece of cake for breakfast. If you ask for water you'll only be given a cup not a bottle. The onboard entertainment is ok with some newer films but not many. The plane seats are pretty hard, not great for long haul.
My return flight from Nairobi to Paris was due to leave at 11:40pm (most international flights seem to leave late at night). This meant I had 11 hours to kill in Nairobi as my flight from Malindi landed around 1pm. I had already checked in so wanted to drop my bags. The desk was reluctant at first to allow this. They said if I dropped my bags I wouldn't be allowed to leave the airport but also it wouldn't be safe to take my luggage around Nairobi. I asked to speak to someone else as it seemed silly that bag drop was open but it meant I was then stuck in the airport. Eventually they agreed I could drop my bags and exit as it was such a long wait. (If anyone else has a long layover I recommend the giraffe centre and carnivore restaurant. We hired a driver called Daniel for a reasonable price to take us round and wait for us and also store bags of our 2 friends who flew with BA and couldn't drop their bags.)
We returned to the airport around 9pm and went straight to our gate. We were due to board at 11:05pm, by 11:30pm there still was no plane at our gate. No communication from the staff until another passenger asked. We were told the plane 'was up there somewhere circling'. Eventually an official announcement was made that the flight was delayed an hour. The gate was very hot and stuffy so they allowed passengers to leave if they wished. Our new flight time of 12:40 came and went, again we were only told of the delay way after the time passed. I left to get coffee and as I was queuing they began to board at 1am. I had to run back to the gate. I paid to upgrade to extra leg room on the return leg which made the uncomfortable seating a little more bearable. The lights were dimmed so people began to sleep only to be woken by the attendants bringing round hot meals around 2:30am. Again, no drinks offered outside of 'meal time'. Breakfast was slightly better than the outbound flight, eggs, potato and spinach with a yoghurt and crossiant. However they leave you with your empty trays for far too long, making you very uncomfy and restricted.
The long delay to our flight meant our 2hr 30 layover in Paris was reduced to 15 mins. Upon landing I mentioned to the crew I needed to disembark quickly and could any ground staff help getting us to our connection. This was just met with a shrug.
Overall I would avoid flying with Kenya airways again. They aren't much cheaper in comparison with much better airlines and improvement is required.

Title:
We booked coach class and then bid a rather absurd amount of money to upgrade the leg from JFK to Nairobi. KQ set the minimum bid at around $1,150pp, we bid the minimum amount, and we “won.”

$2,400 later, we wouldn’t do it again (we actually flew Coach on the way back). Yes, business class is nicer and more comfortable than coach, but it’s not worth that kind of money, especially in the highly likely event that the coach cabin isn’t full.

This isn’t the business/first class treatment you see in the movies and magazines. Chairs are bigger and more comfortable than coach and they basically lie flat, although they’re hardly as good as a bed and at 6 feet tall I had to lie at an angle to keep my feet from pressing against the wall.

The dining trays and monitors are on very cumbersome hinges. it takes some oomph just to get them properly opened and positioned. The biggest problem with the chairs is that they eat phones!! My wife’s phone slid into the cushions and a couple of attendants had to take a goodly part of the chair apart to retrieve. We felt very awkward about causing the difficulty, but then it happened to two other people during our flight!!

Food was fine but again, pretty meh for business class. Movie options ranged from dates to obscure. Service was fine but English proficiency seemed a bit lacking.

I would actually rate the coach class experience better because at least there you get what you pay for. It really wasn’t terrible for a 13hr flight. And I give high marks for KQ opening this direct route from New York to Nairobi. It’s by far the best way to get from the states to central Africa.

But yeah, I wish I hadn’t paid that $2,400 for business class. Not worth it. But if you’ve got the money or the points to waste, by all means enjoy!

We flew to and from New York to Nairobi with Kenya Airways and in my opinion, the company has much to improve on from the customer's point of view.
Starting in New York, we arrived at the terminal 3 hours early. Our boarding pass only indicated the terminal and not the gate. So, we sat in terminal 4 waiting for the screens and the online flight trackers to show the gate number. As the flight departure got closer, the gate number still never showed up in the screens or online. As a result, we almost missed our flight. The only way found out was that the gate agent called my cellphone to inform me that the doors were about to close and to run to the gate as fast as we can. When I told the gate agent about the lack of information, they didn't seem to care.
The food inflight was mediocre to poor quality. If you want to eat something decent, order the vegan option which is fruit. That seemed to be the only good meal option.
The bathrooms got dirty mid flight. One had water all over the floor. A couple of them had ran out of soap and toilet paper.

We arrived early to check in at the desk for our return flight because they wouldn't let us check in online only to be told to wait until 6pm to check in. We returned to the desk at 6pm as told but we were told to go somewhere else as the check in was still not open. At 6:30, someone finally came to the check in desk, but we had to still wait longer as the travel document checker was still not there.
At check in, the agent told us that the boarding time was 2 hours before departure due to additional security measures (after the main secuirty). Of course, the secondary security agents were also 45 minutes late and after we passed through this security checkpoint, we had to wait another hour or so to board to plane.
You could have guessed this already, but the flight also departed 30+ minutes late.
At arrival in New York, after they opened the cabin door, a cabin crew member commanded everyone to return to their seats and put their luggage away without explanation. We were to wait around again.
The only positive thing I can say about Kenya Airways is that they have non-stop flights between JFK and Nairobi, but I might choose another airline if Kenya Airways stays as disorganized and as poor in their customer service skills.
qwuub: An airline with poor customer service and organization

Title: Early morning at Nairobi’s Terminal 1A wasn’t too crowded although try to avoid the first two of several security x-ray lanes once you’ve ascended to the first floor after Immigration for there is no dedicated Airline Crew Lane and crew will walk to the front of the passenger queues and jump in.  That means a lot of crew members at busy times and passengers have to wait.Boarding the 787 was strictly by seat row numbers which really made the boarding process a breeze and the fully laden aircraft was ready to leave ahead of schedule.  Following take-off, a breakfast snack was served: a choice of chicken or vegetarian (small) pastie and a small cake with hot/cold/alcoholic drinks (seated at the rear and receiving all food/drink services last, I was unsure whether passengers at the front had a third choice – usually KQ offer that).  A hot dinner (choice of chicken or vegetarian Bake) was served 3 hours before arrival and, again, not sure if a 3rd choice was initially available.  Just two drink rounds during the 8-hour flight although drinks could be collected from the rear galley throughout.  I’d describe KQs food as basic and bland although I took my own food on board as I know what this airline's offering can be like.With the exception of one uncommunicative and unhappy looking individual whose name badge announced ‘Sylvia’, the all-female Cabin Crew were cheerful and appeared to enjoy their work.  Little information came from the Flight Deck.An on-time arrival into Amsterdam on to a very convenient ‘E’ Gate next to the Terminal hub with a wide range of comfortable facilities and friendly staff. Title: Kenya Airways is the national carrier for the East African country, operating out of the hub in Nairobi.  It flies to several countries in Africa as well as a range of destinations further afield.  It is not a great flight experience which would be ok if the price wasn't so high.The positives around Kenya Airways are the quick check-in.  The dedicated terminal in Nairobi for instance is incredibly quick with hardly any queues mid-morning on a weekday.  It is really easy to get around the small terminal although there is not a huge amount to do there.The on-board experience is ok but not quite as friendly as anticipated.  After being encouraged to take up an emergency exit seat given the need fo the row to be populated there was not really any friendly communication afterwards once the staff had got what they wanted.  Seating is uncomfortable.  The lining of the seat does not make for a great experience for a 3+ hour flight.  The fabric is not tight against the seat structure so creates slight friction.  The design is ugly in any case.  Legroom was ok with enough space for a normal-sized person in either a typical row or emergency exit row.The in-flight experience is minimal.  Food is included and on request a pre-ordered dietary requirement meal was grudgingly provided.  It was not great.  The food was pretty ropey to be honest.  Entertainment selection is limited.  There are not many options.  The television options were largely extremely dull lowest common denominator American comedies while the film selection to its credit did include 1 or 2 classics along with a small range of contemporary Hollywood, Bollywood, and a couple of other options.All the limitations would be fine if this was a moderate cost flight but it is really quite expensive.  A return flight Kinshasa-Nairobi is not cheap in the slightest and so at the price the quality is not good enough.

Title: Early boarding at Amsterdam for the full Kenyan Airways 788 to Nairobi gave us an on-time departure for a flight which ended with an on-time arrival in Kenya. A basic, sufficient and tasty meal with Beef, Chicken and Vegetarian choices was served after take-off with hot/cold/alcoholic drinks although some seated at the rear of the aircraft were denied this full choice since service always commenced at the front and meals were slowly depleted as the crew moved rearwards.  Water rounds continued during the 7½ flight every 30 minutes and a small snack with hot/cold drinks was served an hour before landing.  Despite the 32” pitch and 18.5” wide seats, I was not entirely comfortable and room for manoeuvring was limited in the full cabin.  Kenyan Airways has the scrap line ‘The Pride of Africa’: this is erroneous for the airline service that I experienced certainly wasn’t although I had no complaints and would consider flying with the company again if the price matched other airlines.

There are often delays in the flights - a couple of times they have delayed the flight by several hours and sent a message ahead of time, but other times they don't tell you until you are at the airport. This means that I am afraid to have a short layover in Nairobi, and often end up booking a lengthy layover to avoid delays making me miss my connection. Boarding experience in Nairobi could be much better managed as well. If you pay for the extra leg room seats, they have you board in the last group. You may or may not get personal screens on the shorter flights, depending on the plane, but if you do, the selection is very sparse, not like the selection for the 14 hour flight. I'll continue to take Kenya Airways for their direct Nairobi to JFK flight, because the price can't be beat, but for shorter trips I'd prefer other carriers.

Title: We flew with Kenya Airways last week for our summer holiday to Mauritius. We were flying on two flights-connecting at Nairobi, Kenya. On our first flight from Dubai, we boarded half an hour later than we were due to, this made us depart late and arrived late to Nairobi. The flight had TVs and food and drinks were served but only seen the attendants once or twice, the service was not satisfactory compared to other airlines. We were then due to fly from Nairobi to Mauritius at 1pm, but when we got off our first flight we read on the screen that we were delayed to 21:30pm- a 9.5 hour delay. We only knew about this delay from the screen no other information was given over a tannoy etc. We then by chance went to an information desk to ask why we were delayed. We were informed that the airline staff needed a rest break- we were annoyed at this as it shows how unorganised the airline is! Why do they not have enough staff? When we returned to the airport at 8:00pm for our delayed flight we went to the gate where yet again we were late boarding. We started boarding our flight at 21:30 even though the flight was meant to depart then! When we were getting our boarding passes checked at the gate, the staff member who was checking our passes instructed us to show her our hotel booking and our return flight (even though we were not flying with them on our return). I asked why she needed to see this information and she was very rude back not giving a reason just stating she needed to see both. We were not connected to Wifi or internet so this was merely impossible but she kept us back whilst letting other passengers on without any questions asked. This was very infuriating as we had been travelling now for nearly 16 hours. She EVENTUALLY let us on the flight as another colleague told her to let us on. The airline did not have TVs, little legroom and again the flight attendants were not present often. I will not be flying with KA again as the rudeness of the staff was unnecessary on top of the delayed flight. Please think twice before booking, I would rather pay more and get a friendly and efficient service with another Airline such as Emirates.

Title:
We chose to fly from Amsterdam to Madagascar with Kenya Airways, since we wanted to prevent flying with Air France (their staff tends to strike ever so often).

We were delayed both getting there and going back again.
The first time around the delay happened, because apparantly there is an extra hop in Moroni on the Comoros islands between Nairobi and Antananarivo. This information was not shared when booking the flight. Because of this hop, delay is practically inevitable. It took forever for people to get off and on the plane again. Since Antananarivo was our final destination, it did not cause us any troubles.
It became a problem when we wanted to get back home again after our holiday. Once again, the hop in Moroni took too long, so the plane arrived an hour late, which caused us to miss our connecting flight in Nairobi. Even though we missed the flight by 10 minutes, and the connecting flight was still standing at the gate right next to the one we arrived at, they decided not to wait for us and several other passengers.
After missing the flight, sadly, we had to deal with their customer service, which meant that we were sent everywhere throughout Nairobi airport, dealing with staff that could not care less, and each and every one of them told us different stories where to go to. I lost count of the amount of times we had to go through airport security again and again and again. It was a very frustrating process to go through.

Needless to say we were very happy that the next flight leaving for Amsterdam was a KLM flight! Still, Murphy's law applied, so of course our luggage got lost as well for three days.

The entertainment on the first Kenya Airways flight from Amsterdam to Nairobi was OK, were it not for my headphone jacket to be broken (several other passengers experienced the same problem), so I could not watch any movies whatsoever, which sucks on a 7+ hours night flight. Also, you barely get any water, even though their planes are unusually hot. It caused me to have a severe cough for about a week and a half. They serve your food within one hour after departing, and after that you will barely see the staff again.

Next time around, I'd rather risk a strike than ever flying with Kenya Airways again. I've flown quite a lot already, but never have I experienced an Airline this disorganized.

When I read other comments on here as well, it seems they're delayed quite often, caused by their own incompetence. Please consider this before booking a flight with Kenya Airways.

Our original return to London was originally scheduled for the 8th so we were informed we would do well to find somewhere to go in Kenya so we headed to Mombasa to salvage the rest of our honeymoon. Paying for extra flights and hotels in the process.

Upon time to leave on the 8th June for London we were informed at checking that we infact had a flight for the 5th to London booked by the Kenya Airways representatives at Zanzibar. This flight was never communicated to us in any form (I had emails from after the flight on 5th asking if I’ll require an upgrade for my flight on the 8th).

We arrived at the airport in Nairobi at 5:30am at which point we had 3.5hours to resolve the issue. It initially started with the sales representative and manager claiming our boarding passes for 5th June were printed. After digging into it they then realised not only was it not printed but we weren’t even checked in. We were made to sit in the sales office with the promise that someone had spoken to the controller only to then be told we weren’t boarding our intended flight with no compensation for the now extra day we’d spend in Nairobi (more costs incurred due to Kenya Airways).

Fast forward to the following day and we were able to obtain a ticket on the London flight. After going through check-in, passport control and security I was stopped at the boarding gate as they refused to accept my residence permit for the UK (it was checked and validated at checking and passport control. This is a permit I’ve been flying with for 8 years with several UK entry stamps in my passports (new and old) all referring to the said document number.

I was now staying in Kenya for another day as it was Sunday and contacting the embassy wasn’t an option (incurring more costs). My partner who is a UK citizen got on the flight as she was informed she’d have to pay for a whole new ticket if she decided to stay. There was such a large variety of shows and movies, I was never bored the entire 8 hours! The seats were very comfortable, the blankets given were extremely soft and of high quality. The vegetarian curry served during the flight was delicious and a hearty portion size! The flight staff were extremely friendly and had no problems giving you more drinks if you are still thirsty!
Better service than most airlines!

Would of liked to be aware in advance that when changing to our connecting flight in Nairobi we were not suppose to follow the "connecting flight" signs but actually suppose to exit the airport and cross the road to the domestic terminal. Lucky we made it in time!

Title:

Title:
My flight was delayed returning to UK from Harare. There was no communication prior to my arrival at Harare airport. It took me an hour waiting in the queue before l managed to speak to someone. I was booked on the next available flight which was leaving in 8hrs time.
I was given a Holiday Inn voucher for a room and meals and was told that a shuttle bus was going to pick me up at 22:30 to take me back to the airport.
When l arrived at Holiday Inn, there were no rooms available and staff had suggested booking me at the Crown plaza which l refused as this would have caused confusion with the shuttle bus pick up time.
I was offered to seat in the staff lounge and l rested on the sofa. Came out at 22:10 to wait for my transport back to the airport. Another passenger was also waiting for the same transport since 21:30 as their slot was at that time. Which meant the transport was 40 minutes late.
We waited together until 22:45 and definitely no one was coming to pick us up and boarding was commencing at 23:30.
There was no contact number for anyone to tell us what was going on.
We arranged our on transport to get back to the airport which was very inconveniencing as someone had to wake up to take us and roads are not that safe.
When we got to the airport, there was no explanation as to why we were not picked up. We were told to contact their offices in the morning as there were closed. Not very helpful that was as we could have missed the flight again.
