Title:
This review is of a flight from JFK to Dar es Salaam connecting in Nairobi and return. I hold a Gold Medallion Status on Delta Airlines, with whom KQ is a SkyTeam partner. I shall rate this airline under three rubrics: Counter service, Cabin service and Customer service.
*COUNTER service - outward journey*
We checked in at JFK with no issues. As a Gold Medallion Delta customer, I received Sky Priority Status on KQ. My wife, as my travel companion on the same reservation, also received Sky Priority status. The counter clerk was friendly and efficient. The boarding process is a bit chaotic. KQ does not have clearly bordered-off lanes, so passengers cluster and converge, causing priority boarders to find themselves prevented by economy boarders, thus nullifying the priority boarding process.
*CABIN service - outward journey*
I did not find a "wow!" moment with any of KQ's meals. I found the flight attendants to be reasonably attentive, but not necessarily eager to please. My next comments are among the chief reasons I shall never fly KQ on a long distance flight ever again. First, for a transatlantic aircraft involving a 14 hour flight to have no wifi is like having a flight with no electricity. But wait! There WAS no electricity (in a manner of speaking) on this flight in my seat. The entertainment system did not work. OK, so I could entertain myself by reading, I thought. Hell no! Neither did the overhead lamp work. This was true of all the persons in 19 G, H, and J, and the fellow in 18 G appeared to have the same problem. This was no mere inconvenience; it resulted in loss of work; for I did have work to complete while flying which I now could not; already disadvantaged by the lack of wifi which I had already anticipated. My wife was in 19 F. I and the 19 H passenger drew the attention to these fails more than once to more than three flight attendants. No change of seat was offered economy appeared to be full) and as a priority boarder who entered among the first batch of economy boarders, I noted that business class was nearly empty. Still, the flight attendants offered no apology or options - just surprise that the systems did not work. Make your own conclusion from those details.
*CUSTOMER service - between outward and inward journeys*
This is where KQ has completely lost me. I wrote KQ customer service, indicating the problems outlined above, and suggested (knowing it might have been a long shot) that a fair compensation for the inconvenience and loss of work could be an upgrade to business class on the return home. Even though KQ's automated response says they prioritize upcoming flights issues, I had to write KQ twice - once two days after arrival, and another time four days later (two days before departure) to get a response. The response was not only disappointing, but left me embarrassed at the airline. I felt like I was dealing with a child, caught with hands in the cookie jar and yet claiming it was his sister who was stealing the cookies.
KQ responded that only ONE entertainment cluster on the entire aircraft did not work and that "the flight attendants resolved the matter satisfactorily." They indicated that they could not upgrade us to business class, and ended the email with an apology for the entertainment module (no apology for loss of work, no reference to overhead light, and NO alternative compensation offered for the inconvenience suffered for 14 hours, or my loss of work.
I replied to KQ, trying to remain calm, trying to avoid calling them a liar, and trying to avoid threatening to use all my influence to warn Delta that this airline could tank their record. I succeeded in being polite and calm and used the carrot rather than stick. I never got a response. It is embarrassing for an international airline to LIE and be defensive about a failure rather than accept responsibility and compensate the passenger reasonably. I can't spend my money on KQ again, unless I have no other serious choice.
Before I made this trip, I addressed a question about expectations regarding my Medallion status and transferring of benefits to KQ from DL. Although Delta responded later, KQ's response was more vague than DL's (neither answered as clearly as I think they could have, my specific questions).
*COUNTER service - inward journey*
Because of a crowd at the baggage counters, I and my wife ended up being checked in at NBO separately. Only when we cleared immigration did we notice that we both had boarding passes in -- get this -- my name and both, naturally, included "sky priority." So we proceeded to the lounge expecting that the error would be sorted out while we rested. Because KQ did not grant my wife the same sky priority status as they did on the outward journey, we ended up having to pay for her use of the lounge.
*CABIN service - inward journey*
You won't be surprised to learn that my wife's seat, 20F, would not recline. For 16 hours (the flight was delayed) she sat upright. I am not going to bother complaining, lest KQ lies again. Additionally, the flight attendants this time were not as service-oriented as they were before. Drinks were at a minimum; the food was noticeably of a lesser quality.
During a portion of the flight, I felt unwell, and alerted my wife that I thought I was going to faint or otherwise pass out (I know this feeling and I'm both surprised and grateful that it did not eventually happen). During that time, she went to the galley at the rear (she did not use call button) and mentioned this to a flight attendant who asked the seat number. She said she thought the attendant would come by to investigate. It never happened. Perhaps they might have, if an emergency did arise.
For short flights, with no competition, I'll fly KQ. Next time I'm crossing the Atlantic, or several time zones, somebody else will have the pleasure of welcoming me aboard - not Kenya Airways.
qwuub: Customer Service And Poor Equipment Will Defame This Airline

6. The Nairobi to Mumbai flight was horrible - the Aircon was either not working or not switched on, even after requesting repeatedly. It felt hot as hell. I could not take it anymore and yelled after 2 hours of enduring it and only after that felt some change in temperature - whew!

Title: I want to share my experience with Kenya Airlines.  I checked in 3 hours before my flight to Nairobi this January and when my flight landed in Nairobi by bag was not on the plane.  They told me it never made the flight and when it was delivered the next day, the bag was riffled through and a jacket was missing.  Neither the email address I had been given to contact the airlines or the two telephone numbers were in service to report the stolen items, so I tried to put in a claim two days later at the Nairobi Airport.  No one had any idea how I was to proceed in filing a claim for the missing jacket.  When I returned to the U.S. I found information on the website and after filling everything out I emailed my claim.  That would not do - I had to send it by mail to Nairobi, which I did along with the receipt for the jacket that was purchased especially for the safari.  I did receive a response that they would not pay for the full amount of the jacket, but agreed to 80% of the cost.  I agreed and signed the release which also had to be sent through the US Mail.  Once they received that they asked for my bank account number and routing information so they could deposit the amount into my account.  Instead I asked that they send me a check.  That was over a month ago and today I received an email saying Kenya Airways does not send out checks.  I called my banker and he said not to give them my bank number and routing information because of potential fraud.  Just wanted to give everyone a heads up - not only do their employees rifle through your luggage and help themselves, you won't be reimbursed without jumping through multiple hoops.  Probably because of the incredibly high unemployment rate in South Africa and Kenya, this wasn't my only experience of being ripped off.  This was my 3rd trip to Africa and will be my last.  I would have liked to have been reimbursed for my jacket, but not at the risk of falling prey to another scam involving my bank account.

Title: Firstly, my overall experience with Kenya Airways has been a grave disappointment. I've yet to complete my return journey and hope there is room for improvement. Nevertheless, yesterday was a horrible start for me (being my first experience with KQ in 2018). I was under the impression due to increased capacity in flying to internationally, include the United States, I will be able to begin accumulating mileage with Kenya Airways, but I was sadly mistaken. The message above, was the initial complaint in December. Over the past two months I've had continuous written debate/dialogue with the airline and their "resolution" is 3000 miles or $100 voucher for the same airline. Without considering all of the losses I incurred during this trip. My multiple destination ticket is as follows: depart 10/12 Juba, SS to Kigali, Rwanda (transit in Nairobi), depart 14/12 Kigali, Rwanda to Nairobi (transit in Burundi), and 16/12 Nairobi to Juba, SS. Upon the first flight from Juba, there was an hour delay; as I began to notice the allotted time left, I immediately approached Kenya Airways staff, expressing my concerns. Since the flight to Kigali was 6:30 PM and due to the delay, I would arrive in Nairobi shortly before the Kigali flight departure. Their response, reflected the ability for me to join the 9PM flight by Rwandair, but the system was not allowing them to make the changes from Juba. Therefore I was recommended to immediately approach the help/transfer desk in Nairobi. As optimistic as I remained throughout my flight to Nairobi, my hopes were completely shattered. The rep (unfortunately, I don't recall her name) informed me the next available flight will be Tuesday, 11 December at 7AM. I insisted the rep make a stronger effort to grant me a seat on the Rwandair flight, due to my pending appointments/hotel bookings in Kigali. I even offered to pay a fare difference (even if the only seat available was in Business class; I will pay), but I was unsuccessful. I exclaimed, my medical condition (epilepsy) will be triggered since I failed to put enough medication in my carry on bag, but again was told I will not be able to receive my checked in bag. She offered to place me in a hotel and a free transit visa. I expressed my hotel in Kigali has been paid for and I will not be able to receive a refund, due to this occurrence, but the rep presented no comforting suggestions. Though, I continued to inform the rep, I have a doctor's appointment in Kigali (the main purpose of my short visit-1st time to the city), but she was unable to ease my concerns. Moving forward, I was sent to the rep responsible for issuing the hotel voucher. I insisted the pick-up be at 4:30, but he stated 4 AM is the most appropriate. Being a non-Kenyan; unfamiliar with the main attractions/distance from airport locations, I was placed in a hotel chosen by Kenya Airways. Unknowingly, the hotel was 40 mins away from the airport. I arrived in Nairobi at 6:30 and didn't arrive to the hotel until 8:50 PM. Nairobi was cold and rainy; in which I was highly unprepared for such temperatures causing great distress to my physical state. As an airline highly aware of Nairobi's traffic, I would assume if seeking the best interest of the client, the hotel placement would be fairly closer to airport to avoid any delays, etc. Again, it proved Kenya Airways to be highly insensitive towards the customers. To add insult to injury:•             Since I didn't have enough medication, to prevent a seizure I will have to remain distracted and awake (seizures happen while I'm asleep)•             Without access to my checked in bag, I was unable to shower and struggled to brush my teeth until I borrowed from another hotel guest.•             We were collected from the hotel at 4:15 AM, in the rain; during checkpoint all of the passengers had to disembark from the shuttle bus (in the cold and heavy rain, which I did not have on appropriate attire).•             Upon arrival at the airport, we were dropped much further from the departures' entrance, causing me to run under the rain again.Due to the change of flight, I was unable to see the doctor as planned today. I plan to do a "walk-in" tomorrow, with the hope to receive an opening (which is unpredictable). My four nights trip was shortened to 3 nights and I pray I'm able to receive my medical check-up as planned. This detailed message is written to express the series of events, which has occurred in the last 24 hours. Since, the airport was unable to provide sufficient support nor compensation, I hope this online customer relations is willing to assist in addressing my concerns, struggles and much more which can never be repaid by the airline. Friendly cabin crew dished out hot towels and pre take off drinks did not include Champagne or sparkling wine.
After take off drinks service included a beautiful South African Red Wine, which I had together with a bowl of nuts.
Food service was ½ way into the flight, the menu had choices all straight forward and simple not tasting as great as the food which I had from Nairobi to Johannesburg. No frills, if you are used to a substantial dinner, eat before the flight. The so called Waldorf salad had no celery in it, i.e. just apple and Walnut in a vegetarian Mayonnaise. I did not use the entertainment system, but saw from other passengers that it was working well.

Add to that deplaning in Nairobi meant getting on a shuttlebus to the terminal, filling out a health form, passing through 2 levels of security and you start to get the picture.  We made the flight and the staff was helpful in getting everyone shuttled through their process but if you look at their on time departure record you will see the flight from Nairobi to JFK is always late.  You can see why...they are holding the flight for all the incoming transfers to go through their process which is longer and more stressful than needed.  Also this left no time for grabbing a snack or water for the 15 hour journey ahead. Also be sure to load up your ipad with movies.  The inflight options are not as extensive as other airlines and the choices are the same both eastbound and westbound.  For a 15 hour flight this needs improvement.

Service on KQ these days has become very variable ranging from amazingly good to amazingly bad, often at the whim of the flight crews and, more often than not, its the female crew members who seems to be the least helpful. So would I fly KQ again? I am not really sure. Short haul for sure but long haul has so many alternative options that have more comfortable seats, better food and better service that the decision needs careful consideration. I will let you know.

Title:
I was super excited to travel to Zimbabwe and see Africa for the first time and got the perfect excuse when one of my closest friends from college planned her wedding in Harare. My outbound flight on American Airlines was cancelled due to weather, leading to me missing my connecting flight on Kenya Airways. While this was unpleasant, no one can control the weather, and AA helped re-book me on a later Kenya Airways flight into Harare, Zimbabwe, so I made it on time to the wedding.

After a few weeks of seeing Victoria Falls and making friends with lions, I got back to check into my flight back to the States with Kenya Airways. The attendant there helpfully let me know that I had been marked as a “no-show” on my outbound flight, and now my return ticket was cancelled as a result. After arguing that I clearly was re-booked on a later outbound flight, given my presence in Zimbabwe, and would very much like to return home, Kenya Airways told me I could get on the flight if I paid a “penalty” of $1200. As I had already paid for a round trip ticket, which typically include a flight home, I indignantly refused to pay for my flight a second time and wound up missing the morning flight. Two more flights back to the States came and went, and I missed all of those flights as Kenya Airways demanded ransom payments to let me out of the sweltering hot airport onto a plane. I racked up hours of international cell phone call payments with American Airlines customer service and my travel agent, who all let me know that Kenya Airways was not picking up the phone, and they were the only ones who could get me on one of their planes.

16 hours later, having missed every single flight that day, I finally gave in and paid the $1200 “penalty,” or really, the ransom payment, in addition to the $1600 round trip ticket I had already paid, and Kenya Airways let me on the flight back home. For the privilege of nearly doubling the cost of my plane ticket, I also had a 17 hour layover in Nairobi, after which Kenya Airways told me my flight to JFK was overbooked. At this point I had resigned myself to the fact I had probably died and was in some new circle of airline hell, but fortunately Kenya Airways did one thing right and found a seat for me onto the flight back to the States, which I had paid for twice. All in all, I wound up spending nearly four days total in airplanes and airports, racking up international phone charges, and nearly doubling the cost of my Kenya Airways ticket.

Kenya Airways, the Pride of Africa.

Title: Having heard mixed reviews about this airline, I decided to try it for myself before casting judgement. The entire online booking experience was promising and the ticket fares appeared to be competitive. I received numerous e-mails following the booking offering opportunities to upgrade to Business Class. Our routing was from Johannesburg to Nairobi on KQ763 (a short 4 hour flight on a Boeing 737-800) and then a short 90-minute layover at Jomo Kenyatta Airport before connecting to flight KQ886 which would take us to Bangkok. When checking in online the night before our flight, I experienced difficulty with the website which claimed that there was a "system error" making it impossible to complete the online check-in (even though I had completed all passport and other details for the two passengers travelling). I contacted the local office in Morningside, Sandton to be told that we could only check-in at OR Tambo Airport and should get there 3 hours before the flight. Later the same day, I received a SMS from the airline informing us of a 7,5 hour delay for flight KQ886 for "technical/operational reasons". On landing in Nairobi, I approached the airline desk to be told that we would be taken to a hotel close by and brought back in the morning to catch our flight to Bangkok. It was clear that there were many other passengers in the same situation as well as those who had missed connections due to late arrivals. After waiting for three hours in the airport we boarded a bus and drove for approximately 30 minutes to the hotel. They were not prepared for our arrival at all and chaos ensued. The meal that had been promised was not ready and it took another 45 minutes to get room access. It was 2:00am before we got to our room and we were told to be in the lobby at 4:00am for the return to the airport. At 4:00am there was no transport in sight. Fearful of missing our flight, we decided to hail an Uber taxi at 5:00am in order to get back to the airport. This fiasco led to us missing our domestic flight from Bangkok to Koh Samui, we missed one night of accommodation at our resort and also our pre-paid airport shuttles that were to take us to our destinations. This incompetence is such a pity considering that, once in the air, the flights are not bad at all. Service is friendly and efficient, the aircraft are clean and new (Boeing 787 Dreamliner is a great aeroplane) and the meals, whilst a bit small, are not bad at all.

Title: The point is that most of us fly economy and still pay a lot of money for these flights. Kenya Airways are not low-cost, and for regular working people, these flights are a substantial chunk of our savings. We work hard for this money and then spend it in good faith hoping that our hard work will be reciprocated with good service, newer airplanes, decent food, and on-time departures and arrivals. After all, we schedule vacations around what is possible with our jobs and kids’ school schedules. Kenya Airways who boast being “the Pride of Africa” are only missing the point. The point is this “good faith” must start at the top and trickle down. If there’s no real leadership at the top, the employees down the hierarchy will have no incentive, accountability, or feeling of ownership when it comes to providing a certain level of service. A smiling face of a CEO dressed in expensive clothes and watch is just missing the point. If you only cater to business/first travelers and forget about the majority economy travelers, you are missing the point. The feeling I got flying Kenya Airways for the first and last time is that it’s missing a certain culture which is so important for customer loyalty. The point is that if a plane is 15 years old and unpleasant, especially the toilets, but the service and timeliness of flights is on a high level, one does not notice the equipment. Our trip from Cape Town to Bangkok and back was the worst I’ve ever taken with any airline. Everything was matter of fact. Except for the last leg from Nairobi to Cape Town through Victoria Falls (which was still the wrong return flight and 24 hours too late) ALL flights were delayed between two and twelve hours. The on-board meals are half the size of comparable flights and mostly junk. Drinks cart selection looks like Aeroflot in the 80’s. Kenyans are warm and inviting. Is there a reason why that cannot be the same at Kenyatta airport? Is Kenya Airways not the major airline of that airport? When there’s no culture at the top, there’s no culture on the ground. Rude immigration officers and security personnel throwing bins at passengers. And everything done at snail pace, with total disregard and matter of fact. There are many wonderful and accommodating employees along the way, but that is not the point. We all tend to remember the negative and unpleasant, but the right kind of culture has no room for negative. Customers have choice, and if enough customers stop using Kenya Airways, will that make its point? ANY paying customer must not only receive the same high level of treatment the CEO would receive, even if our cutlery differs, but return home praising the little things. That IS the point.

Title:

Title: This is a long flight but a whole lot better than connecting through Europe or the Persian Gulf. If a flight is just going from point to point this is a fabulous flight. If a flight is an opportunity for an experience of any nature then there's not much about this flight that stands out. I should point out that the flight from Nairobi to New York, as the New York to Nairobi flight, was just about half or less than half empty. I had 3 seats to myself both ways so for me those flights were very comfortable but you can't depend on that. Shortly after takeoff from Nairobi we got a very meager dinner, arguably the least impressive of all the dinners I've ever had on comparable flights in economy. No one expects great wine in economy but the red wine I had on this flight was at the low end of that already low range. On the outbound flight I had a couple of packages of macadamia nuts, a VERY impressive and delicious improvement over the tiny bags of peanuts you get on a Delta flight. But on the return flight there were no nuts at all (I was looking forward to them). The movie/TV selection was good enough but not exceptional. The breakfast was  better than the dinner the night before so that slightly redeemed the meal aspect of the flight. The flight crew was very friendly and accommodating but how much can they do for you in economy? It was really a great flight, but only because I had 3 seats to be able to lie down and sleep comfortably. I would still opt again for this flight just because it's so much more convenient than connecting through any other airport.

Title:
My husband and I had the most terrible trip with Kenya Airways today. We were supposed to have a 1-hour stop-over on our way to a much anticipated and relaxing holiday at Zanzibar. But then this happened...

We got onto our connecting flight on time. After driving to the point where we should’ve taken off, the pilot announced that there were some technical difficulties that should be checked. So we drove back to the ‘parking spot’. And there we sat. In a closed airplane. For at least an hour.

I should also probably say that this was an early morning flight, so we would’ve gotten breakfast. But alas, no.

After an hour in the plane we were asked to get off as it was not safe to fly.

Then we followed a guy to the domestic flights desk and there we were for another 2 hours (without any food in the vacinity) just trying to get a new flight ASAP. It took exactly 1,5hours for the manager to show up, and after a lot of fighting we heard that we could get a flight later that evening.

So, we got a flight - yeah! On the same day that we paid for - yeah! And we got 4 hours in a hotel to freshen up plus lunch - yeah!

However, I’m still quite angry. I missed my first day of my 7 days in Zanzibar (I know I sound so spoiled). But, hey, they say time is money. And this time was not worth the money.

Think twice before you choose Kenya Airways as a stop-over on your way to a nice idyllic holiday. It might just make you more stressed out than you were before.

Title:
There is a reason some airlines consistently get bad reviews - they are BAD!
I travel a lot and Kenya Airways without doubt gets the prize for worst airline this year.

I was flying Kilimanjaro to Seychelles, changing planes at Nairobi. Kenya airways cancelled the first flight, didn't tell me & rebooked me on a later plane - which arrived at Nairobi 3 hours after the onward flight had already left there! How stupid was that?!

Buy merest chance I discovered this mistake a week before the journey, and managed to change the first flight to an early one which meant leaving the hotel at 3 a.m.
Meaning this simple journey would now take about 16 hours of travelling including a massive stopover in Nairobi. NOT great for 65yr olds.

Had I not discovered the cancellation in time, we would not have reached Seychelles that day. We could not have stopped overnight in Nairobi as we had no multi-entry visa.
We would have lost hundreds in hotels and booked onwards arrangements.
It turns out that first flight is cancelled regularly - typically 1 day each week.

Did Kenya Airways care or try to do anything for us? Not a thing.
I asked Kenya airways if, given it was their mistake, we could have access to rest in the Nairobi business Lounge or even get an upgrade to business (only 4 seats in business had been sold on that flight so lots and lots of room)

No, nothing said the agent.
Fill in our customer form said Facebook.
Zero response from customer services, then or since
Utter waste of time.

In the event we paid to upgrade to business. What a waste of money! The Business Lounge was tiny and poor. Meals in business class were worse than in most Airlines economy. Oh and the plane from Nairobi took off and arrived late (for no good reason) making the day even longer.

And guess what: I got an email inviting me to check in for the flight - that had been cancelled.

Kenya Airways are lucky they have a captive market of Kenyans, because I can't see any European ever flying with them more than once!

You have been warned. Choose a different airline!

Title:
As a specialist tour operator, several times a year I fly back and forth to Kenya, and usually have up to 100 or more guests flying into the country over a season.

In August/September this year I decided to give Kenya Airways a try as they had added new Dreamliner aircraft to their fleet. My flight up to Nairobi which I upgraded for my wife & me to Business Class was very good.

However when it came to the time to return I once again checked online, saw the scheduled aircraft was the Dreamliner, and once again upgraded three seats, mine, my wife’s and my nephew’s, who’d worked the Mara season with us and I thought I’d give him a little reward.

However on arrival at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport the morning of our flight, September 29, there was great confusion and consternation until they admitted we’d been downgraded back to Economy...despite the fact I could show proof that my upgrades had been approved and my Visa card debited.

The airline ground crew were very apologetic and it appeared that there may have been some important politicians wanting to fly that morning, as well as the fact that the aircraft was downscaled to an old 737.

Fortunately we did manage to get our check in luggage accepted at the Business Class allowance (Note: Kenya Airways allows Economy passengers only half the allowance that SAA allows. This is an important consideration when going on a long safari. Kenya Airways gives you 1x23kg, SAA 2x23).

Later, once already seated on board, the aircraft cabin staff approached my wife and me and offered us seats (not together) up front in Business Class but left our nephew in Economy. So much for the kid’s big treat.

We were told by the cabin attendant to apply for a refund once we got back to South Africa, though they did not have the forms they should have given us for this application.

Hahahaha!

KenyaAirways have given me the total runaround over this ever since. I have sent them copies of tickets, boarding passes, the letter of approval for the upgrade saying my Visa card would be debited and still I wait.

Every time I contact them I get redirected to a website to fill in and supply the exact same details all over again.

Now seven weeks later I think I have to give up...and I will certainly NOT use Kenya Airways again. I will also warn my guests against this airline as customer service and satisfaction seems to be very low on their agenda. You have been warned!

Don’t Fly Kenya Airways

Title:
On 07 Sept, 2018 my wife and I were travelling business class by a Kenya Airways flight from Mumbai to Kilimanjaro. Two pieces of baggage were through-checked-in from Bangalore(our origin by Jet Airways) to Mumbai to Nairobi to Kilimanjaro. One of the two pieces arrived in Kilimanjaro while the other got left behind in Nairobi (night of Sept 07/08).

The loss of one piece of baggage was recorded by Swissport, the baggage handling agent in Kilimanjaro, with a promise that it will arrive in a later flight from Nairobi and be delivered at our hotel in Arusha (Mount Meru Hotel)

After several phone calls to Kenya Airways Central Contact Centre and constant follow-up throughout the day with the Swissport agent in Kilimanjaro, we were told at 7 pm on 08 Sept 2018 that the baggage has arrived but we have to go over to Kilimanjaro Airport to collect it, The airport is about 50 Kms away and we were to leave by a very early flight the next morning (09 Sept 2018) from a small airport in Arusha to a safari camp in the interior of Tanzania. It was going to be very inconvenient and taxing at that time of the night to travel a total of 100 kms to get back our baggage.

In the first place, the airlines goofed up by delivering only one piece of baggage and leaving the other midway, which is a great inconvenience as all my clothes were in the lost piece. Secondly, asking us to go over 50 Kms to collect the retrieved baggage was cruel (Kenya Airways should take this up with their agent, Swissport). It was extremely annoying to handle the guy on duty at Swissport on the night of 08 Sept 2018. So, we requested the Duty Manager at Hotel Mount Meru, Arusha to help us, which he willingly did. He took it upon himself, though it was not in his line of duty. He went out of his way to uphold the pride of Tanzania as a tourist destination. He was very clear in his mind that the guy at Swissport, Kilimanjaro Airport, was duty-bound to deliver lost baggage to our hotel and eventually ensured that it was done. I have written about this not-so-common show of initiative by a Duty Manager at a hotel in my review of our stay in Hotel Mount Meru, Arusha on 08/09 Sept 2018.

Kenya Airways would have to (1) take it up strongly with Swissport to ensure that its employees adhere to contract terms (that would have been entered into between themselves) and (2) put in place fail-safe practices at Nairobi airport, to ensure that piece-meal loading is avoided (either both pieces of baggage arrive or both pieces are lost, you can't have a little bit of each, that too at a major hub, Nairobi, the headquarters of Kenya Airways). It has been my habit to always check with the airline's agent at a transit point (when boarding) whether the baggage has been transferred. To my utter disappointment, the agent at Nairobi looked into the computer and confirmed to me that the two pieces were indeed loaded. This was obviously a big bluff.

The intention of this feedback is to ensure that Kenya Airways takes note of these lapses and provides better service in future.
qwuub: Kenya Airways' Agent,Swissport reluctant to deliver Lost Baggage at our Hotel in Aursha (50 Kms from Kilimajaro Airport)

Title:
Just arrived in NYC after flying Kenya Airlines newly opened route from Nairobi to JFK!!

I started my journey in Johannesburg. Check in was smooth. Although they couldn’t give me my boarding pass for the second leg of my journey!

Kenya Airlines utilize the Bidvest Premier Lounge at O.R Tambo. Which is decent. Quite busy. But not chic. The newer SLOW lounge shared by the other SkyTeam airlines is way cooler and has a much better selection of drinks and food.

The flight to Nairobi was delayed by an hour (but we made up the time en route) with an on time landing!

Boarding was a little chaotic. Better signage would help.

On board the hard product is great! The Dreamliner has a 2-2-2 configuration. And has three rows in one cabin, separated by the boarding doors and galley and then two rows in a second, directly in front of economy.

I was fortunate to be in 2D. Middle row in the front cabin for both legs of the journey! I need to point out that there are no overhead bins available for rows 1 and 2 center seats. But saying that there was plenty of available space on both flights.

This seat is one of my favorites, plenty of space. It’s a lay flat. And is super comfy and wide. I would take this seat, with the risk of people sitting next to me or climbing over me. Over some of the smaller, cramped all aisle access seats that are out there. (Think Delta One 767!)

I slept a solid 8 hours on my second flight!! And close to two hours on my first!

The service on board was actually quite good. The FA team take huge pride in what they do and they are genuinely honored to do the work they do. Personal standards are on point. Think Emirates!!

The food was actually really great! On my first flight I had the beef Babotie - which was AWESOME. (The food on both flights was really good!)

On my second flight I had the vegetarian option - the giant gnocchi, which was nice. For the mid-flight snack I had the pizza slice. (Although I think the burger may have been a better choice). And for the huge breakfast I had the fluffy omelet with chicken sausage. Included in breakfast is a fruit selection, yogurt, cereal and muffin. One of the biggest breakfasts I’ve ever had on a plane and only beaten by Emirates 1st Class.

A decent selection of beverages is offered as well. The only downside is there is quite a delay before being served the first beverage after take off!

They don’t use duvets on board, and have opted for blankets instead. At first I was not a fan. But actually these are quite nice. The pillows, however, are quite flat. I snagged a second one on my first flight which made a big difference! Not so lucky on the second flight as Business was 100% full!

The IFE system is great and has a decent selection of movies, TV and Audio options (including audio books).

Deplaning in Nairobi was seemless. Security was pretty smooth as well. The only drag is that I was not able to get my boarding pass until much later. After being directed to the transit desk.

I knew I was going to be in Nairobi for a long layover and checked into the brand new Four Point Sheraton - which is fabulous. Going though passport control can be quite a process. And took longer than anticipated.

Hint - the taxis are quite a scene and the drivers are super aggressive. Even this 6’2 hardened New Yorker felt a little apprehensive. If you’re staying at any of the airport hotels. Email in advance and have their courtesy car pick you up. Learn from my mistake!

Check in, passport control and security at Niarobi was once again smooth. The lounge is small and despite being new looks quite shabby. But then again, some of the travelers using it have little respect for it either. Which is quite sad.

Be prepared for a quite intense second security screening before boarding flights for the USA!

And the boarding process was a bit of a mess with almost everyone rushing to board at the same time. Kenya Airways will have to address this! I had maneuvered myself near the front, so was one of the first to board!

Overall - Kenya Airways offers a really good hard product, great service and food and beverage choices. They will need to address the boarding process and a look at how they manage the lounge in Nairobi. I paid a little over $2000 for a round trip Business Class ticket from JHB to JFK. (I think as part of their inaugural promotions) Which is a really great bargain. Saying that. If the price gets closer to the completion. I may select to stick with KLM or Virgin Atlantic.
qwuub: Kenya Airlines - solid business class at great value!

Title:
My sister and I arrived at the airport for our Kenya Airways flight to Nairobi with connection to Dar Es Salaam on 8/8/18. We were supposed to be picked up from the airport in Dar Es Salaam by our tour guides and taken straight on a 3 day safari. We booked and paid for our flights with Kenya Airways 2 months ago believing Kenya Airways to be a reliable airline. When we arrived 2 hours prior to our flight to check in, we were told that the flight was full. Despite the fact that we had arrived within the requested time to check in and had paid 2 months prior to the flight, we were kicked off the flight. There were multiple other passengers that also were not able to check in because of too many ticket sales - 1 of them had been able to buy a ticket that same morning online despite there obviously not being any left! We purchased our tickets 2 months ago - how were there still tickets on sale the same morning and yet we, who purchased our tickets 2 whole months ago were kicked off the flight?! This is unacceptable!! Another had arrived 2 1/2 hour prior to departure and had still been kicked off. He had also purchased his tickets much later than we had!
We were out in a hotel for the night with boarding passes printed for the next flight in 24 hours but also with the promise by Kenya Airways staff that early the next day they would try to find an alternative flight to get us to Dar Es Salaam earlier. We were already going to miss our airport pickup, who was taking us straight onto a 3 day safari for which I had already paid $300 US for. We were interrupted during breakfast to rush back to the airport. The staff told us we had been booked onto an Ethiopian airways flight through Addis Ababa but they did not have flight details to supply us with. They cancelled our tickets for the Kenya Airways flight that night. After a long wait in line, the check-in staff found only 1 ticket, rather than 2. They couldn’t tell us arrival time in Dar Es Salaam but checked in our bags and a long time later gave us boarding passes. On checking them, we discovered our route would now include a 26-hour stopover in Addis. Not only were we leaving a day later than our initial flight, but we would be now be arriving 48 hours later - a whole 24 hours later than if we had gone with the later Kenya Airways flight. On showing the staff at Kenya airways what they had swapped us over to, they then told us the Kenya airways flight that night was already full and we couldn't fly. Seriously, this was ridiculous. We were made to go back to the hotel and brought back to the airport that evening without any communication as to whether we would even be flying.
There was no offer of any compensation for the mess made by Kenya Airways - no upgrade, not even an airport lounge, no offer of a partial refund, not even an apology, even after I filed a customer complaint via their website. Instead they just say they pride themselves on customer service over and over again. We had a completely wasted day with massive amounts of stuffing around by Kenya Airways. None of it was due to anything that we did wrong. ALL of it was because Kenya airways overbooks their flights to make extra money. Won't be flying with them again.

Title:
I was continuing my overnight journey from London to Cape Town after changing planes in Nairobi. My luggage was checked-in through from London.

Nairobi was hot and humid and there was air conditioning in the airport. There was a long queue to get through security and it was very busy at 05:00.

We boarded the Embraer aircraft after a bus tranfser from the airport. The flight was full. I had my pre-booked window seat as requested.

Great view of Mount Kilimanjaro very shortly after take off from the left had side of the aircraft.

The cold refresher towels were a nice touch after the tropical humidity of the airport building.

Hot brekfast was served about 45 mins into the flight. It was tasty enough but very little. Cabin crew were friendly but could have been more generous with the juices and water as many of us had transferred from other flights and were thirsty.

The stopover in Livingstone was uneventful. KA was the only only aircraft on the apron. Passengers continuing to Cape Town could not disembark the aircraft and some passengers had to change seats for the second leg of the journey.

The in flight entertainmet system did work but I had already exhausted what I wanted to see on the overnight flight from London to Nairobi.

Shortly after take off from Livingstone we were served with a bar service and lunch - which was very welcome. Luch was tasty. The red wine was particularly good.

The conncetion to Cape Town was only 2:45 and we expericnced some turbulence for the final hour of the flight, so had to keep seat belts fastened.

My luggage arrived safely in Cape Town.

Title:
On July 2, my wife and I were scheduled to fly NBO-LHR on Kenya Airways, then on to the United States on Delta. I am a US citizen and my wife is a Kenyan citizen with a US permanent resident card (aka "green card").

All went smoothly until the agent checking paperwork at the gate immediately prior to boarding denied boarding to my wife based on the idea a transit visa was required in the UK, when in fact no transit visa is needed for our situation.

To make matters worse, when my wife returned to the ticket counter for further assistance (as instructed by the gate agent), she was told there was nothing they could do for her and that she would need to purchase an entirely new ticket. She purchased a one way ticket on KLM for $1550.

Of course I immediately filed a complaint with Kenya Airways and insisted on reimbursement. After numerous inquiries into the status of my complaint, and being told an investigation was ongoing, I finally received an email on October 4 in which Kenya Airways admitted the situation was entirely their fault. They offered $300 compensation.

After several more emails back and forth, I've concluded they will never make things right and accepted their $300 offer. It's impossible to argue with an airline headquartered in a developing country with no real consequences for appalling customer service.

Their 787 aircraft are nice (does any airline have a 787 which isn't nice?) but I would stay far away from Kenya Airways. You never know what sort of shenanigans they will pull and there is no way to hold them accountable after the fact.

Title:
I arrived at the airport at 5 am so i could board my flight to Harare leaving Nairobi at 715. Flight KQ706
Upon arriving at the check in desk, I am informed that the flight was overbooked by 30 people and i would need to be put on another flight
I offered to pay extra to upgrade - to no avail. I then accepted to be on KQ704 departing at 1410
A KQ desk attendant called Mary assisted me (good service) quickly, printing out my boarding pass and checking in my bag for the 1410 flight.
She passed me on to William for the compensation and the action whilst i wait for my flight at 1410 (KQ704)
William was struggling with the load of the KQ706 customers that had faced the same problem. There were some very irate people. After about and hour he then assisted me by helping me to get the $50 compensation
He then tells me to go through immigration and look for the KQ desk inside the airport
I did exactly that. At arrival at the KQ desk i was informed that the resolution to my issue was actually a hotel stay up until my flight. However I needed to exit immigration to be assisted. So William had given me wrong instruction.
I asked the ladies at the desk if i could at least stay in the airport and be given seating in the KQ lounge instead of exiting immigration again and they said that they could not give me seating in the priority lounge and my best solution to comfort was the hotel.
I considered this and I did exactly as they recommended as it was still early…730am or so.
I waited in a que at the KQ desk at the arrivals terminal for about 20 minutes. I was finally assisted by the lady who then sent me to the shuttle to go to Summerdale ‘hotel' with a voucher
I boarded the shuttle which was cramped.
I suffered through the traffic. The shuttle had 3 drop offs , Tamarind, Weston and Summerdale.
When we had traveled about 20 minutes the driver stops at a lay-by along Mombasa highway and swops with another driver. That was my first point of worry, but i let it pass.
We continue and in about another 10/15 minutes, the bus starts smoking ( i have a video of this- the video also shows the dingy quality of the bus)…it was smoking from the inside and outside….all the passengers were concerned and we all raised alarm.
The driver just asked people to open the windows and we proceeded
The driver says we should carry on to Tamarind where he would get another bus. Finally boarded bus which arrived at Summerdale Inn (not Hotel as the voucher indicated) at about 930. The Inn is in a horrible looking part of town and looks like a 1/2 star establishment .
Rooms were not ready
We were told to go to breakfast.
At breakfast the food ran out. What was left was off, the bacon had a stench and smell.

KQ responded to my complaint with a long email justifying why they overbook...(because they do not think 30 people will make the flight) and offering me a silly $50voucher. Not acceptable.

Title:
I've flown with Kenya Airways a few times now and each time my flight(s) were delayed. The connecting flight to Accra is scheduled to depart at 1am but it seems like nobody told the crew about it... it only leaves at 2am. On my last stopover in Nairobi the flight was delayed because they did not have any crew to operate the flight. It was first delayed by 4 hours and then by a further 10 hours. Only when passengers started to make a scene (after the 2nd delay was announced) did Kenya Airways realise they needed to do something to make it up to their passengers. It took them an hour to get the passengers allocated to hotels and on unroadworthy transport. When arriving at the hotel we were told that the airline did not notify the hotel so it took them a further 2 hours to get rooms available so we could freshen up and take a short nap before getting onto another unroadworthy bus to the airport with signs allover saying you should buckle up but not a single seatbelt available.
If at all possible I will never again fly Kenya Airways!!!

Title:
I'm from Kenya and even a shareholder of Kenya Airways (KQ) and i would love to fly and promote the airline all the time... unfortunately though, i usually only fly it out of convenience due to shorter journey time. Even this may start to reduce further after my last flight. As i climbed on board, the supervising attendant on business class greeted me warmly and said they would try and make my journey a very pleasant one. This all started going wrong immediately after take off - i went to use the washroom and all of a sudden the door behind me opens. One of the attendants opened the door without even giving me a second to respond after knocking... it was ridiculous and thankfully my back was facing him. He never came to even apologize until i raised it with the supervisor later. I'd even let that go... but then it was time for lunch. The starters were served and i waited patiently for my main course. The passenger next to me then tapped me on the shoulder and asked if i had ordered anything and when i said yes, she felt really uncomfortable as she has finished her meal and i was yet to be served - i said it must be taking long but after another 10 mins or so she called the attendants to ask and they had forgotten my meal and said they now had to heat it. 30 mins passed until i called for the attendants again and this time the supervisor came - apologized that they had run out of the option i picked and so were taking one of the crew meals that was the same and needed to defrost and heat that up. All in all i got served over an hour after my fellow passenger was served.
Something else to note is Kenya airways won't serve you champange unless you ask for it when you first board. No water bottles are provided either again until you request for one.
For the price you pay, the value for money and service is sub-standard compared to the likes of Emirates. The skyteam lounges also do not compare to the Emirates lounges.
I may still fly KQ, but it may be more out of convenience... if i don't have to worry about time, i'm definitely sticking to one of the other airlines which has a higher level of comfort, better food and way better service!
qwuub: Convenient to fly, but business class service standards need a big step up in comparison to other airlines!

The trip started at the business lounge at JKIA. The lounge is modern and comfortable and offers internet which is not the fastest but it's good enough for light streaming and work. The lounge offered a good variety of drinks and the food also was varied and tasty. The service was awesome despite the high number of travelers inside the lounge. This lounge is definitely 10/10.

The flight was a little bit late about 20 mins which is very very good for Kenya Airways... About 1.5 to 2 years back the norm was 1 hour if you are fortunate and all types of questionable reasons were given.

Once inside the flight was comfortable the food was good and the drinks choice was good. Kenya Airways have really changed for the better.

The only reason they don't quite get a 10 is because the selection of movies was very limiting and the choices of what to eat was also very limiting. They only offered one type of red wine. Apart from that the service was outstanding.

I look forward to a business class trip in one of the bigger planes over a longer distance since this was a small Embrier.

Title: Traveling around Africa generally can cost a lot, both in time and money.  The ticket price will be high, the travel time long, be very expensive, and most times you have to leave the continent to travel from one country to the other.  Luckily, there are African companies that are making travel within Africa more affordable and convenient; both Ethiopian Airlines and Kenya Airways.  Both are the flag carriers of their respective countries, both seem to have updated fleets, good schedules, and both seem reliable.  I was looking to travel from Nigeria to Tanzania, and return from Rwanda back to Nigeria and in looking at my options both Ethiopian and Kenyan came up in the search.  Both were competitive in price and both had about the same overall travel time, but I choose Kenya Airways for a couple of options: 1) I had flown Ethiopian on my way into Nigeria so wanted to try another airline; 2) it had been about 4 years since I had flown Kenyan so wanted to see what updates were available; 3) the departure timings for Kenyan were better; and 4) Kenya had more options in terms of flight scheduling. Booking travel with Kenya was very easy through the website.  The site was easy to book and manage your reservation.  I had to make some modifications to my reservation and that could not be accomplished online, so they either have a chat function available or a call center; both of which were helpful.  Another good feature about Kenya is that they offer refunds on your ticket – if your schedule changes and you need to cancel your ticket, you can ask for a refund instead of travel credit.  The refund amount depends on your ticket and class of service, but everything is available online and usually the refund is processed within 4-6 weeks.  A great service from Kenya.After booking my flight, I managed my reservation through the Kenya Airways app.  Through the app and website I was able to preselect my seats for free, request a special meal, and add my Skyteam frequent flyer number.  I was also able to check-in and print my boarding pass directly from the website 24-hours prior to my departure.  My first flight was from Lagos to Dar Es Salaam via Nairobi.  The Lagos to Nairobi sector was scheduled to depart Lagos at 10:45p and arrive into Nairobi at 6:05am, and then I had 45 minutes to connect to my other flight which was scheduled to depart Nairobi at 6:55am and arrive into Dar Es Salaam at 8:20am.  This was a tight connection, but this is what Kenya Airways provided me and everything was booked on one ticket so I went ahead with it and hoped for the best.  The first flight was operated by a Boeing 737-800 with a 3-3 seat configuration.  The aircraft operates the Nairobi to Lagos sector, and the same planes brings passengers back to Nairobi.  The incoming aircraft arrived late, and the turnaround time was slow, thus boarding began well past the 10pm which was listed on the boarding pass.  Boarding was done by groups and the groups were strictly enforced; this made for a lengthy and delayed boarding to an already delayed flight.  First impressions upon entering the aircraft were good, as it looked like a new-ish plane with updated seats and personal PTV for each seat.  Each seat also contained a blanket, a pillow, and headphones on them.  The seat pitch was decent, not too tight but not too generous either (I am 6’1 and while my knees were not hitting the back seat, there wasn’t tons of room either) and the seat comfort was also average (it was fine for a 3hr flight but there needed to be more comfort for the longer flights).  Each seat contained a PTV with a USB port and headphone jack, a tray table, and then a seatback pocket with the airline magazine, the duty free, and an airsickness bag.  The doors finally closed, we pushed back for the gate, and headed to the runway for the 5hr 20mi flight to Nairobi.Kenya Airways is a full service airline so complimentary meals and drinks are provided.  Once we reached cruising altitude, the meal and drink service commenced.  The special meals were delivered at the same time as the regular meal, and for the regular meal there was an option between two choices.  I had ordered a special meal and while I appreciate being served a meal (as these days meals are disappearing from economy), the quality of the meal was not that good.  It was a decent quantity, not too much food but not too light either (perfect for a 4hr flight) but the quality of the food definitely need to be improved.  Complimentary soft drinks, tea, and coffee were also provided.  Once the meal service ended, passengers sat back and watched their screens.  The PTV screens were already on once you sat down, so most passengers just watched the entertainment program the entire flight.  There was a decent selection of TV shows and movies, again good enough for a 3-4 hour flight but you would get bored on longer flights.    Even though we departed late, we landed roughly on time and taxied to the gate.  There is a separate line for transferring passengers, but because Kenya is starting new flights to the U.S. they have modified the transit so all passengers must go through enhanced screening.  While I understand the security of this, it adds time to the transit process and this needs to be factored into the connection time they provide to customers.  There was a HUGE line of passengers in the transiting security line and it looked like I was going to miss my connection when the airline itself started to call out passengers for my flight.  A representative was pulling passengers and putting them ahead of the security line as I only had a total of 25 minutes to make my connection.  Since I was moved to the front, I went through security and ran to my gate in time to make it to my flight.The second flight was operated by an Embraer 190 with a 2-2 seat configuration.  While the plane size was small, the seat pitch and comfort were nice and each seat had its own PTV screen as well as USB port.  The plane was only half full so the doors closed and we pushed back for an on-time departure.  Since there were not that many passengers, I was able to move up and stretch out to a row unto myself.  Even though the flight time was 1hr30min, a light breakfast was served just after take-off.  The breakfast consisted of a fresh croissant which was nice, warm and fresh.  It was small but it was nice and that is something I appreciated from Kenyan, especially on this short flight.  Tea, coffee, and complimentary drinks were also served with the meal.  Once the meal service end, most passengers either slept or watched the entertainment system.  The system was not as extensive as the system of my Lagos to Nairobi flight, but there was a decent selection of TV shows to pass the short flight time.  We soon landed in Dar Es Salaam and luckily my bags also made the tight connection in Nairobi.My return flight was scheduled differently than my outbound flight.  I was returning from Kigali to Lagos via Nairobi, and I had scheduled a long layover in Nairobi.  My flight was scheduled to depart Kigali at 8:30am and arrive into Nairobi 12:35pm, and I was then going to connect to my flight departing Nairobi at 6:35p and arriving back into Lagos at 9:50pm.  The first flight was operated by an Embraer 190 and has a stop in Bujumbura.  The flight was supposed to board at 7:45am, but that came and went without any announcements.  Finally, the announcement was made and we boarded the plane.  This plane looked similar to the plane that I had taken from Nairobi to Dar Es Salaam, with the same legroom, the same individual PTV’s on each screen, and the same 2-2 configuration.  The flight time from Kigali to Bujumbura was only 45 minutes so most passengers past the time watching their screens.  The passengers on the plane consisted of passengers flying from Nairobi to Bujumbura (who stopped in Kigali); passengers flying from Kigali to Bujumbura; passengers flying from Bujumbura to Nairobi; and passengers flying from Kigali to Nairobi (who stopped in Bujumbura).  We landed at Bujumbura, where some passengers got off while others got on, and set off for Nairobi.  Since this was a longer flight, at 1h55m, both a beverage service and a meal service were provided.  The flight was uneventful and we landed in Nairobi close to on-time.After a scheduled delay, I fought my way through Nairobi traffic to connect to my 6:35p flight to Lagos.  Even though we had boarding groups assigned to us, these were not enforced and everyone boarded as they pleased.  The operating aircraft was a Boeing 737-800, the same aircraft that brought me from Lagos to Nairobi.  The layout was the same, the seat pitch and seat comfort were the same, and again each seat had their own PTV screen.  As this was my fourth flight with Kenyan in the span of two weeks, I had basically exhausted the entertainment options by this point.  As the flight time was 5hr15m, after takeoff a meal and beverage service were provided.  For the rest of the flight, the attendants were not present at all until it was time to get the aircraft ready for landing.  They attendants did not come by with water or to pass through the cabin to collect trash; the attendants just sat in the back talking.  After a bit of a delay, we finally landed in Lagos a bit behind schedule.Overall, it was a decent experience with Kenya Airways.  Since my last experience with them, some aspects have improved while others have stayed the same.  They definitely have a better on-board product versus what they previously had, and that makes for a better inflight experience.  The food quality still is average, and the overall customer service still needs to be improved.  I had some great flight attendants and great customer service, and I had some really apathetic ones.  I would not hesitate to fly them again, but I would just keep my expectations manageable.

Cabin crew was efficient and worked smoothly without fuss. Later after the breakfast drinks were served. It included Soda, wine ,beer, tea, coffee with handful variety of juices to choose from. I chose Fresh Apple. In-flight entertainmaint worked well but the headphones had defective left earpiece. I was then given another one.
Soon after that cabin crew asked me a cockpit visit. As I entered the cockpit Capt. Simon masau greeted me and said "We dint forget you yaa!" This was something so good of them. Later my journey was commensed on the jumpseat. I had a great time with Capt Simon and F/O Kalya Glenn. We cruised at 34,000ft and landed at NBO with a delay. soon after I had to rush to my connecting flight gate. While rushing towards Gate14, I heard my name getting announced at the terminal for the final call. They held the connecting flight to Mahé for me- Something airlines tell but rarely do.

Conclusion- They are worth considering and are a cut above some of the African competitors in terms of food and comfort.

Title:
As I always do I watch for the opening time of the online check in and then change my seat to a more preferred location. This worked well for the CPT NBO sector but that is where it ended. I could not check in for my onward flight KQ8520 NBO EBB and eventually gave up frustrated that I had to go to the airport to drop off my bag ahead of the flight without a boarding pass for my final leg.
The Kenya Airways staff at the airport in CPT were helpful but also defeated, unable to offer any explanation why they too were unable to check me in for my final leg.
The flight then left on time, positive and eventually reached Nairobi 45 minutes early, a life saver for me to make my connecting flight which was taking off from a different terminal making an endless walk necessary.
But first things first ... In my meal did I find a piece of plastic in the slice of cake, kept it for the crew, handed it to them and it was taken without any apology or regret. I hope it was reported after landing because that should not happen unless for careless catering staff and poor quality control.

Transit in Nairobi was a nightmare for me ...

First, arrival security control at JKIA had ONE, yes ONE station operating and the queue kept growing and growing by the minute, of departing passengers from Nairobi being screened alongside more connecting passengers from flights just landed. By the time I reached the front of the queue three other stations had just opened, and of course those coming last were served first causing audible curses and comments from those who had stood in line for long.
Next, in addition to the regular and often mind boggling stuff one sees at security checkpoints, I was asked to remove my scarf, which in the worst of scenarios did not resemble a weapon and anything of metal below would have been captured by the scanner. Well, given the short fuse security agents have these days and the gusto with which they bundle objecting passengers to interrogation cells for strip searches had me bite my tongue but I think my face told him what fate I wished upon him.
Finally through, my scanned scarf once again tied around my neck I was able to get to the transfer desk of Kenya Airways. There, after enduring another lengthy wait, I was then told upon brief inspection of my itinerary print that I should proceed to Gate 5 as the lady at the KQ counter ‘could not help’ to get me a boarding pass. Pointing at the KQ flight number did not help either but prompted her to say one revealing and one outright s***** thing: One was that their systems are not aligned and she could see my booking on the KQ system but but could not act on it as she had no access to the Jambojet system. Second I was told that Jambojet was wearing pink while Kenya Airways was wearing red uniforms which showed they were different and could I now move to make space for other customers queuing behind me.
I reached Gate 5 after a mile long trek through the entire next terminal, exactly half an hour before departure – and had KQ 785 not landed 45 minutes early I would have reached Gate 5 only after the flight had been closed.
The Jambojet staff, when hearing the story, apologised for the inconvenience of not getting a boarding pass on check in or at the KQ transfer desk, apologized for the long walk and then, lo and behold, I had to go through another security check?!? Thank you but no thank you JKIA and KAA, this was as pathetic as it comes!
Same routine with laptop out, again, shoes off, again, pockets emptied, again and belt buckle removed, again BUT, no one bothered with the weapon of mass destruction around my neck, aka scarf, this time … so much for consistency and training of those deployed to operate the checkpoints.
On board of Jambojet, notably no life vests but a demonstration of how to use the seat as a flotation device, again having me thing of the unthinkable, when the passengers are busy first dismantling their seats before they could escape out of a sinking plane …
And, of course, full fare ticket notwithstanding, I was asked to pay for tea and a snack which on a proper KQ service would have been included in my fare for a flight on the same sector.
My conclusion, never again a codeshare combination which involves Jambojet and for a long time no return to KQ as long as I can avoid them.

Title:
My friend and I flew with Kenya Airways from London Heathrow to Entebbe via Nairobi. It was our first time flying with them, and the leg room and value for the flight is what sold it to us.
On the day of the flight we received a text at 2am telling us our flight had changed to 11:30am - it was originally planned for 6pm. This was then followed by another text which told us it was actually delayed to 8pm. Then followed by a few other texts telling us our connection was delayed then it was not delayed - in the end the 2 hour delay resulted in us having 25 minutes to catch our connecting flight.
Boarding time was 6:30pm, we didn't get on the plane til 7:45pm - there was no explanation to why the plane was originally delayed and followed by another delay. Once on the plane, it was followed by another 1 hour delay due to 2 passengers missing and having to remove their luggage. Finally took off about 9pm which resulted in us missing our connecting, however this was delayed too and once we got to Nairobi there was a quick smooth process. We were handed our new boarding passes soon as we got through security and guided to the right gate.
The plane has very good leg room and we were on the dreamliner which was a new plane - the windows have the new tinted option instead of blinds. However, my headphone output was not working so I could not watch any of the limited in-flight entertainment provided. The food was very basic and was still hungry afterwards. The flight attendants didn't check up on passengers during the flight either.
HOWEVER, even though my flight out was a bad experience and very frustrating the flight home was much better. Everything was on time, smooth process and we even landed 35 minutes early. Plane was comfortable, got given baby wipes once we setlled. 2 hot meals, a snack and plenty of drinks throughout the journey! The other good thing is you get snacks on the short internal flights as well, flight from Nairobi to Entebbe is less than an hour and we were provided croissant and yoghurt!
I think you get what you pay for with Kenya Airways, I would consider flying with them again.

Title:
I flew from Johannesburg to Nairobi on the 1210 hrs departing flight and then connected after a 3 1/2 hour layover onto the 2055 hrs departing flight from Nairobi to Mumbai. Both legs of the journey they have the new Dreamliner aircrafts. The seats are great and so are the TV screens with plenty to watch on the Entertaiment program that they have. There was only one problem though. On the Johannesburg Nairobi flight they did not have any headsets for people to use in the economy section (not sure if they had the headsets for the business section) for the entire plane. I’ve heard of flights having a few faulty headsets or even a few short but have never heard that they forgot to load the headsets for the entire plane. Service on this flight was not the best but no major hiccups.

On the flight from Nairobi to Mumbai, however, the service was really very bad. I was on an aisle seat and next to me was a lady who was not well travelled. After the dinner service and some time in the night she remembered that she needed to take some medicine and needed water and asked me how could she get some. I promptly pressed the call button to get one of the attendants to get her some water. A few seconds later the call light went off but no one had come. This went on for the next 20-25 minutes and every time we pressed the call button the light would go off in a few seconds but no one would come. Finally one of the attendants from the front in her way to the back asked what was needed. When I told her that we had been calling someone for so long she just casually shrugged and then went away. She did manage to bring the water a couple of minutes later.
Sadly once the meal service is over then no one is bothered about any further service. No point having great new planes if the service is not improved.

Title:
I must have done the CPT to NBO routing at least 50 times or more with Kenya Airways, but this was the first time ever that I took the direct flight (so no stopover/connecting flight in Jo'Burg but direct Cape Town to Nairobi with a fuel stop in Victoria Falls on the way out and Livingstone on the way back)
On both outbound and inbound flights the KQ pilots went out of their way to give everybody in the plane a good view on the beautiful Victoria Falls....people in the aisle seats were swapping their phones to the people in the window seats so they could take pictures...and first the people on the left side of the plane had the best view and later the people on the right side.
It was so funny, as everybody was so excited and it really felt like a school excursion!

We flew on the relatively small Embraer 190 plane, the nice thing is that it's a 2-2 seat configuration in economy so no big rows. The food was excellent and I was impressed that we had 3 meal choices on this plane, in economy.
Staff very friendly as usual, entertainment system relatively limited on this smaller plane, but still ok and the flight isn't that long (6 hours or so, much faster than doing CPT - JNB 2 hours + connecting time minimum 1.5 hour + JNB - NBO 5 hours)
I would definitely recommend this flight, and airline.
Safari sana!

Title: Four staff checking in eight flights inevitably meant a challenging queue with very little information coming the way of any anxious traveller. Many took to leaping through the barriers. However, once through immigration, the new side of the airport is a huge improvement on the other side (most other airlines). Coffee shops and duty free sparkle at you and the best thing of all... toilets in the departure lounge. KQ itself is in my opinion now better than British Airways. The plane is a Dream Liner and lovely and new. British Airways tends to schedule its oldest, most knackered aeroplanes or this route. I'm sure they rattle. On KQ the entertainment is excellent and they give you two proper meals unlike BA. You don't have to pay extra to book a seat before the flight and the onboard toilets are cleaned regularly. Also you can take far more luggage. Much better option if flying to Nairobi and can cope with a bit of queue barging on the way back. Hint... on the way into Nairobi sit near the front of the plane and fill in your visa form beforehand... available online. This gets you though immigration much faster. Leave plenty of time to get to the airport in Nairobi as the traffic can be hell, especially if it's raining.

Title:

With such a long time in a 737 the 7 hours to Accra is awful as the seats are rock hard and food very poor. This is long haul when the offering is domestic level for a full charging full service run. Entertainment is ok, if you get a newer plane but still well below top priced experiences.
You then sit onboard in the plane for 1.5 hours in Accra in boiling conditions with no air on. No drinks, no nothing and toilet use is limited as the plane has to be cleaned and this is priority for KA.
Then a short trip to Monrovia and more mediocre food and another 1.25 hours in the plane on the ground , no aircon no nothing and another clean over dance on board.

Plus side, had the please of doing one trip business class and to put it mildly it's worth the ride if KQ offer it to you as a free upgrade but I would fork out that cash if I were paying.

Title:

1. When we were in transit in Kenya, the ground crew declined us from boarding and said we need to present return ticket otherwise we can’t get in...with extremely terrible, careless cold attitude. We never been told we need the return ticket to get in the flight/entering the country before. We flew through the same airline and no one told us about this, we almost missed our flight.

Details:
Me and my boyfriend are frequent flyer and we already travel in africa for 3.5 months for 8 countries and we never had problem with flight transition in every airport/ country here.

Yesterday we flew from Zanzibar Tanzania to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia through Kenya airline. We checked in Zanzibar and we had all of our boarding pass/ luggage direct to Addis Ababa straightaway which is great. We only need to transit and wait in Kenya airport for 2 hours then we go- everything was perfectly ok.

Until we tried to boarding at gate in Kenya, the ground crew who called Mary she said we have to present the return ticket from Addis Ababa otherwise we can’t get in the plane. We were so shocked cos no one told us about this issue and we never been requested before.
So we asked: “but why the crew who checked in us to here didn’t mention anything ?”Then she replied coldly: “they only checked from Tanzania to Kenya, they are not responsible for this transit.”We were like how can this sounds like you guys work for different company and we are the two idiots.

She insisted we need to buy the return ticket otherwise there’s no way we can get in. Look at the time - We only had less then 10 minutes before gate closing but she only replied: you still have 5 minutes you can buy ticket now ...with careless attitude and totally ignored we were constantly telling her- we can get the visa on arrival for sure and we checked online before, there’s no need to present return ticket for visa (which this has been proved is true that we spent less than 10 min to have the visa on arrival in Addis Ababa by the time we got there).
She just walked away and we don’t understand why she declined us when we were in transit and she even is not the immigration office, also please remember if return ticket is a must thing to have then you should have told us when we were in Zanzibar not in Kenya! She even said we will move your luggage cos you can’t get in...

We were so panic but had no choice to buy the ticket on the spot... you can imagine how slow was the airport WiFi...and all the pressure.
Then we finally allowed to get into the plane at the very last minute.

This is not the end of the story, i was then found my backpack cover missing (my only luggage is a 50L backpack with the cover) then I noticed one of my small backpack which was put in the layer was missing...it was very obvious showing this must be taken from somebody intentionally. (cos I put the bag under the layer tightly, there’s no way it could fall from my backpack)We are super disappointed about this big airline. Title:

I had substantial layovers in all locations, especially in Kigali, all of which I chose purposely. The exception was Burundi. On the way back to Dar, I went from Entebbe to Nairobi to Dar. This flights were also smooth and customer service must have been fine again, as I do not recall any issues.

I enjoyed Kenya Airways and if I find another great deal with them, I will fly with them again.

Connections via NBO were a bit longer than I would have liked but really I certainly wouldn’t dissuade anyone from booking them.
Thank you Kenyan.

Title: Probably one of the few airlines that could fly into Kenya. We are Singaporeans, so we flew into Bkk and transferred to Kenya Air to enter Nairobi.  Went on Economy and it was bearable.  The flight was stable, the food average, the service was not too bad and toilets were quite cleane.  BUT, the biggest bugbear here was the timing.  We were ready to head out to Nairobi from Bkk at midnite S'pore time.  However, the flight was so badly delayed that we only managed to take off only at 4am+!  That affected a lot of things esp those at Nairobi.  The layover time was 3hrs, the delay was another 3.5hrs, all in all, we sat at Bkk airport for nearly 7 hrs!  But still, all was good and we took off. On our journey home, I decided to give my family a treat and upgraded (with payment) to 4 Biz Class seats.  It was much better and this time, surprisingly, no delays!  It took off on the DOT!  Wow, what a treat. Biz class here is as per other biz class.  Not any better nor any worse if you compare against EUR or USA liners.  However, it would lose out to Asian liners I would imagine.  Seats were generally cleaned, reclined to straight and level, bigger screens, champagne to kick-off the flight, blankets were thick n fluffy, headphones were diff from those in Econ class, etc.  We had seat nos 3s and 4s.  So we were in the first sector of the aircraft just behind the cockpit.  As such, we had no disturbances from the Econ class side as behind us, there were another 5 rows of Biz Class.  Very quiet and lots of privacy.  Our family slept like babies and before you knew it, they were announcing to descend!  When we landed, we yearned for more time in the Biz class but...., and we landed with fresh minds and fresh bodies, very little lethargy unlike from Econ class.   If you asked me, I reckoned its all worth the upgrade and I am happy I gave my family a treat like this.  Conclusion - DO IT!  Do it the biz class way....
