Title: In June 2017 I booked a flight to Hanoi for myself and my daughter through TRIPSTA. We were to depart at 12h10 on 1 December 2017, stop over at Nairobi and then straight to Hanoi. In October I booked a flight (again through TRIPSTA) for my son who decided to join us.The only flight I could find for him was JHB-Nairobi-Bankok-Hanoi. I decided to book this particular flight because the three of us would at least have been able to fly together from Johannesburg to Nairobi. When we got to the Check-In Counter of Kenya Airlines I was informed that there was a problem with the tickets for me and my daughter. I was told that all flights from Nairobi to Hanoi have been suspended since 1 October 2017 and that the Booking Agency was supposed to have rescheduled our flights! I was told to contact TRIPSTA to sort out the problem. To my horror the woman I spoke to at TRIPSTA told me that there is nothing that can be done they will refund me!!?? My son had to get onto the 12h10 flight and I had already booked 4 Domestic flights in Vietnam (all paid for in advance) as well as 4 different hotels for our holiday there (Time for free cancellation of the Hotel bookings already expired) I was devastated. It was imperative that we fly to Hanoi on 1 December and not a day later. I explained this to the Check-In Clerk of Kenya Airlines and he referred me to their Booking Counter to see what can be done. They were really kind and understanding and immediately started searching for alternative options. At the end of the day my son left on his scheduled flight and me and my daughter followed at 17h10. It was such a relief I didn't even mind the 5 hour wait at the Airport. Many thanks to the Kenya Airlines staff at O R Tambo for your support and friendly assistance!

Title:
On the Heathrow to Nairobi route there are only two options British Airways or Kenya Airways, we'd never flown with Kenya Airways before and they offered an excellent package which we decided to try.

From start to finish for both the outbound and inbound flights from the moment we entered the airports and proceeded to check-in everything was very smooth, efficient and also very friendly whilst still being professional.

Easy boarding onto the Dreamliner gave favourable impressions with other operators of the type we have used and the business cabin at the front of the aircraft have seats which go fully flat as well.

The cabin crew were very presentable (in charming red uniforms) and efficient and offered drinks, meals and other items in a pro-active way which was very relaxing and made the 8-9 hour trip enjoyable and every detail of the service was well thought out.

The food was particularly good and with some tasty options.

Both flights were on time and disembarking was just as good as embarking - the business lounges at each airport were very good indeed.

Nothing was too much trouble during any stage of the flight process and Kenyan Airways should be proud of the service and product they fly - they style themselves as The Pride of Africa and we found this notion was well upheld.

There was nothing we could fault and would recommend the Kenya Airways service between Heathrow and Nairobi highly - BA are very good but Kenya Airways better still.

Title:
With reference to our recent Kenya Airways flight experience I believe that you would benefit from my personal observations and comments regarding your services.

Flight KQ492 Dar-NBO- 03/08/2017
Overall a pleasant flight, but the in flight entertainment system was not working in our seats on the emergency exits or from what I could see about (4) fours in front of us. I asked the flight attendant to check for us, she told me it was being rebooted. It never worked for the entire flight.

Flight KQ760 NBO-JNB- 03/08/2017
Overall a pleasant flight the 787 aircraft is a delight, however I would suggest you ask your Executive Chef to travel on one of the flights. To be offered a “poached egg” with green bean/pea stew and fried cubed potatoes was to say the least disgusting. I could have played golf with the egg which was cooked so long it might have bounced. Not an experience you would want to remember.

Flight KQ 765 JNB-NBO 09/08/2017
The check in was an experience I have never in 40 years of flying encountered before, the person who designed and implemented this process should be fired.
1. Stand in line to have your bags weighed, not only that but hand over your passports while the airport rep completes many details in a log book, after which she gives me a paper to hand in at the check in desk.
2. At the check in desk the airport rep again takes our passports and weighs the luggage, and completes her checks and issues the boarding cards. ( Not sure why she needed to re-weigh the luggage).
3. We are then instructed to carry our bags to a different check in desk where they offer to plastic wrap our bags, a) our bags are already wrapped, b) the machine is not working as the man can’t find an extension cable. We are told leave our suitcases at this point unattended- ‘not a problem’ we are told as I was unhappy to leave them in the middle of the check-in hall. “no problem’ we are again told the security man is watching them. He must be very clever I stated as he is facing away from the luggage texting on his phone.

4. We board the plane on time… however it soon becomes apparent that all the passengers who had been clearly required to remove excess luggage from the suitcases, have now gained considerable hand luggage… as what was coming on board was not going to fit in the overhead lockers, I felt sorry for the flight attendants who were under considerable pressure to assist passenger until the ground staff who were the same ones that had checked us in came on board to assist.
5. The consequence was a slightly delayed departure.
6. On arrival in Nairobi only a few minutes late due to tail winds, we were further delayed as we had to wait a considerable time to get a parking space.
7. Once off the aircraft we moved quickly through the airport, with great assistance from security officials as we were now getting late for our connecting flight to Dar es Salaam KQ480.
8. The PA system was announcing final calls for the flight, the TV screens were showing final call we arrived at the gate.
9. We were met with the most unfriendly KQ agent who told us the flight had left, as I could clearly see the aircraft at the gate and as the PA system was till announcing the flight and the TV screens still showing final call, I was shocked that she refused to board us. As I pointed out from her system she must have been able to see our connecting flight had landed, she must have known we were on that flight, but no help was offered.
10. We joined a queue at KQ Flight Service, with two agents working and a line backing up through the Duty Free area, after 35 minutes in the line the agent without any apology changed our tickets to the KQ482 departing at 11:00hrs. I was then told to return to the desk at 08:30hrs to collect Breakfast Vouchers, I could not believe she was serious!
11. We collected our Breakfast vouchers at 08:30hrs, as instructed and were directed to gate 23 Avanti Restaurant for breakfast. On arrival we found one lady behind the counter and approx 40 guests already seated. We asked about the breakfast and were told the breakfast was “egg, sausage and bread with tea or coffee” we were told to take a seat and someone would come to take our order. After 15 minutes and the arrival of more than 30 more people from another delayed flight I asked when we could order, she was now very confused and under pressure and told us she had already ordered our breakfast, another ten minutes and it arrived, a one egg overcooked omelette and the second one one overcooked fried egg both with a sausage and two slices of toast, no butter no preserve, no condiments on the table.
12. We eventually went to the boarding gate delighted our journey was almost over. I did bring to the attention of your agent at the gate that as well as welcoming KQ premier passengers to priority board she might also add inconvenienced passengers as a gesture that KQ was sorry for the inconvenience… I don’t think she liked my suggestion.
13. No problem we departed on time and arrived in Dar es Salaam on time at 12:15hrs.
14. Waiting for our luggage in Dar es Salaam one piece arrived on the conveyor belt, we waited until the belt finished for the second one, it was not there and went to lost luggage to start the process for our missing piece.
15. OH! to our surprise the one missing luggage had come on the KQ 480. So you also allow unaccompanied baggage on your flights, I understood this was against all the security recommendations.

If you have taken the time read through this letter, and digested the contents you will appreciate the distress the actions of your employees cause to your passengers. Not a single apology throughout this ordeal. I thought I would bring this to your attention as I am sure your passengers face these problems every day, and even though in the big picture this is a minor delay in your eyes, you can clearly see how the endless problems arise from simple issues, You have a big job on your hands to turn this around but I hope you manage it. I think it will be some time before I try again.

Title:
We had a great time on our 9 day vacation tour of Nairobi, Mt. Kenya, Sweet waters, Lake Elmenteita and Masai Mara. The hospitality was excellent with amazing service of ever smiling people. We had formed an impression of Kenya being incredible with all our initial apprehensions put to rest until our debacle with Kenya Airways at Dubai.

Finally, it was the Dnata Connection Desk staff & Duty Supervisor appreciating our plight since 0615 hours took it onto themselves to get us confirmations on the Oman Air flight ETD 2250 hrs.

It has been a harrowing and tormenting experience for me and my wife all of 17 hours we spent at the Dubai T1 because of Kenya Airways inefficiency and lack of sensitivity.

Having braved the time, the least we expect from Kenya Airways now is a compensation for the Ordeal we went through for no fault of ours. Title:
KQ (as they are known) is a reasonable carrier but there is much room for improvement. Being almost a monopolist in east-Africa makes that they sometimes give the impression they couldn't be bothered...

Although they like to give the passenger the impression they're the best thing what could've happened to them, the service is average to poor, the food is very mediocre and the equipment needs (superficial) maintenance. Panels are loose, tray-tables are sagging. We can only hope that major structural maintenance is under control.

There's no consistency in their operations, sometimes you have to wait to get pulled to a gate upon arrival, sometimes they're allowed to taxi themselves to the bridge. Sometimes you get to a bridge at a gate, sometimes you need to bus back tot the terminal. They claim that's all due to external circumstances, but forcing the people to stay in their seats after engine shut-down 'cause stewardess needs to walk through the cabin to check the front door... take a leaf from other airlines and learn.

Finally, the lounge. Being a Frequent Flyer I see this lounge sometimes every week. The food is dismal, choice is limited and never varies. It's too busy from time to time and the bathrooms are an afterthought. Not worth it...

However, there's hardly any choice in east-Africa. The network of KQ is very good, so people tend to stick with them.

Title: Travel on a fairly regular basis to Kenya. Last 4 trips have been on BA (premium economy ). I like to the day time flight on BA out of Heathrow  it gives us  a late evening in Nairobi . Alas, now at terminal 3, which in my view is the worst terminal  at Heathrow. And at nearly £1200 each for BA decided to give KQ business a try as they  were doing a deal for Business and internal flights, which we had 5 , 2 in Business . Reviews of KQ were not that positive on the various websites. However,  Check in, super smooth and fast track into the Lounge , which was very good and  set the tone for the flight. Staff,  Attentive and professional , none obtrusive  service through out  the night  flight. Day time flight back to Heathrow as was even better. Bar set up for self service on the flight after the main meal which should be the norm. Overall worth the extra money . Internal flights on KQ were good and apart from the Mombasa to Nairobi which was 40 minutes late, everything went well.  The Lounge in Nairobi  for out short flight  to Kisumu was good . The Lounge at Mombasa prior to the flight back to Jomo  is very poor. Food was appalling and cold . You have to pay for Wifi ( apart from the first 15 minutes, why bother. You have to pay for alcohol and a very nice  person spent 15 minutes seeking a Tusker for me, which was warm. Plenty of boxes on display which you can purchase and they will be microwaved for  you! . The Lounge at Jomo the next day prior to the flight to London was a little better. Although, we must have got there at the end of breakfast . Had to chase down staff for plates and cutlery   and food!. at least the Wifi was free! . Apart from the moans re the Lounges in Kenya I was impressed by the over all service from KQ and suspect that BA are not going to tempt me back in future flights to Kenya.

Title: I would like to be able to review our flight from Cape Town to Victoria Falls. However I can't, as it never happened. Given we had booked into a safari lodge for that night, this cost us about $2000 ( party of 5).  we were told that ground staff in JNB would look after us and make all hotel and meal arrangements. It was probably another 15 minutes before our arrangements in Cape Town were finalized( no idea how long people behind has had to wait!) When we arrived in JNB, the staff there knew nothing about the cancellation and seemed to spend most of their time chatting with colleagues instead of helping customers.  On top of that they were rude.  I understand flights get delayed and even cancelled for circumstances beyond control of airlines.  No idea why our flight was cancelled, but Kenya Airways failed to properly notify us, failed to provide sufficient support in CPT to make arrangements for the passengers and failed to ensure staff in JNB were prepared to assist. Title:
On our incoming flight our bags did not arrive.
They arrived 2 days later... just in time for our friends wedding... after being rummaged through and some gifts opened.

Outgoing: We were alerted at 1:30 am that our domestic 4am flight to Nairobi had been resheduled to 8:40am. This meant we missed our connecting international flight to Amsterdam at 7:55am.

When speaking to the operator 'Wangare' we were told she would call us back. after waiting an hour still no call. so at 2:30 am we called again to be told 'just get to Nairobi and they will sort you out there'. After spending 2 hours waiting for answers in Nairobi we were told we were booked on the flight the next day. They did offer us a hotel but we have friends in Nairobi so we stayed with them. We were assured our taxi fare would be reimbursed. No surprises that this was later refused.

We were travelling as a family and they had split us all up, luckily the kind air hostesses managed to swap some people around and sit us together.

The plane was cramped and the entertainment limited. the 'continental breakfast' consisted of a packet of nuts and some juice. There was pee on the bathroom floor, when I asked for a blanket for my sleeping baby I was told they were for business class only, and when I asked for some milk... the flight attendant forgot.

The service was slow, unsympathetic and inefficient. Considering all the mistakes they made, it seemed like it was up to us to fix them ourselves.

Despite being 'checked in' by Kenya airways to our final destination in Stockhom, when we reached Amsterdam the KLM flight had no knowledge of us and we had to explain the situation to them. They then reprimanded us for not having checked ourselves in properly!

All in all, what should have been a straightforward 11 hour journey, ended up taking... from 1:30 am monday 24th... to 8pm on tuesday 25th. 43 hours later. No compensation. No upgrade, No sympathy. Nothing.

I will NOT be flying KQ again.

My one gripe was with the return from NBO - ACC. Flights within Africa are expensive and notoriously unreliable so to find one that is well-priced and gets you & your luggage to your destination (mostly) on time, is rare and worth exploring!

Title:
I'm writing on behalf of my mother and sister who traveled from Lilongwe to India for my mother's medical checkup. To start with, booking the flight was a roller coaster. Prices kept changing, from the time they received a quotation to the time of payment. The price drastically went up all in a space of less than one month. Top that, their flight was delayed and no reason was given.

The major problem was when they arrived back in Lilongwe (on a Wednesday), they discovered that all of my Mother's luggage was missing. After reporting the matter to the officials, they were only able to trace one of the bags which was apparently left in Mozambique. This bag reached Lilongwe on Saturday and lucky enough it was protected in plastic wrap. After inquiring for the other bag they kept telling her it can not be traced and to call back the next day. On Saturday, they still could not trace it and assumed it was in Mozambique as well, they tried reaching out to the colleagues in Mozambique but were told to wait till Monday so that they can check in case the bags was with customs.
The bag was located and for some reasons best known to themselves, they sent the bag to Nairobi (VIA MALAWI) and Nairobi had to send it back to Malawi. By then this Tuesday. If the bag fiasco wasn't enough, when the bag arrived, my sister noticed that the bag weighed much less than before. They opened the bag only to find that EVERYTHING that was NEW - Every single Item that was bought on their trip - had been stolen. A couple thousand USD worth of items all stolen. My sister completed a compensation form, so we will wait to see how that goes.

I feel very disappointed and sad for my mother, who went for a critical medical checkup to have undergone such tremendous stress with this airline.
A number of my friends have complained about Kenya Airways - from delayed flights not only for hours but days which ended up with them missing their connecting flights, to rude flight attendants, baggage missing as well as theft of items from customers bags. And one sad thing was that when my sister went to collect the first bag on Saturday, she met a guy who was from Gambia, His luggage also went missing on a Kenya airways flight. He came to Malawi for a one week conference and unfortunately all his stuff were in the missing bag and the only items he had were the clothes he had on that day and a very small hand luggage.

From my mothers experience and what I have heard from friends, I wouldn't recommend Kenya airways to my worst enemy. It is a complete mockery to other airlines and very incompetent.

To Kenya Airways, your services are beyond dismal and disgraceful! You should run a matatu bus service, not an international airline.

Title:
OK, so I thought I would be clever and pay the lower price and grin and bear it if it was a bad experience. Not a good choice on my part.
Where to start? Well, maybe in Dubai. I have to say that the check in there was about the best part of the whole experience. It was frustrating as the boarding counters only opened 3 hours before expected departure, and by that time there was a large and rather confused gathering of potential passengers, without a Kenya Airways staff member in sight.
Kenya Airways, as with other airlines that have online check-in, will need to establish a better system for dealing with bag-drop customers, as the line and waiting time for bag-drop was longer and moved slower than the standard check-in queue.
The whole process was redeemed by a very efficient and friendly lady on the check-in counters. she smiled at everyone and was incredibly helpful. Kudos to her, she was the best staff member I encountered on the entire return trip.
I guess I should have also known that traveling on a 737 to Nairobi, and then again to Johannesburg was going to be a challenge. The Kenyan Airways 737-800's I flew on are not really adequately equipped for a 5 hour flight
The seats were close together, and not very comfortable. On-board entertainment was adequate, but the headphones are antiquated and require passengers to attempt themselves to put on felt covers, which are not the easiest things to handle. Especially first thing in the morning. My mood wasn't helped by having to get up a few times before we even took off to allow the people seated next to me to move, as they had sat in the wrong seats.
I was also shocked when the cabin announcement came over that we should remain vigilant and keep an eye on our hand luggage as there may be theft on the plane.
The flight itself was OK, with reasonably palatable food. The lady who eventually sat next to me sadly decided to spread herself out too, making my experience even worse.
The changeover at Nairobi was also poorly handled. Jomo Kenyatta airport can have all the upgrades it likes, but the ground staff's incompetence is not dealt with they can expect worse reviews. The initial departure gate was changed, and the announcement over the PA was unintelligible, The television displays were also not changed to show the new gate. it turned out that the PA announcement was also wrong. Eventually we all got on board though.
The flight to Johannesburg was equally uncomfortable, made even worse by the most awful meal I think I have ever been served on an international flight. The beef was one large blob of gristle. Yuk. The flying itself was smooth, I can give some credit to the pilots.
The return trip on 7th January was better only by virtue of it being on a brand spanking new 787. I arrived at check in early, and I was glad that I did. I am still not sure that I understand what happened. I had one suitcase weighing 27kg, and a hand luggage bag of approximately 8kg. The luggage allowance for economy class passengers is two bags of 23kg. For business class it is 2 bags of 32Kg.
I had one bag, but because it weighed 27Kg, I was asked to empty out 4Kg into my hand luggage. If I could only have one suitcase at 23Kg then I understand. I was 19Kg under my total weight limit, and the 27Kg suitcase was not a handling issue, as Kenya Airways accepts 32Kg cases from business class customers. Please be warned future economy class flyers. The big thing for me was not even having to unpack and repack, but the joy that it seemed to bring to the ground staff who were instructing me.
So to Nairobi, where once again I witnessed a display of incompetence so obvious it was painful. Firstly we were delayed in leaving by over an hour. passengers were asked to go to the departure lounge as if the flight was on time. This lounge started filling up. No announcements were made at all informing us of the reason for the delay or that there was a delay. this is very poor. Then the coup de grace. The ground staff member who is now responsible for allowing passengers on to the flight (bearing in mind that all passengers had been screened at the door to the lounge) decides in his infinite wisdom to open the doors to the airbridge.
Passengers then got up and formed a crush at the open door, where they were then told through a raised and panicked voice that the plane was boarding by zone and that everyone should remain seated. That was not going to happen. It was bizarre to see business class passengers and families squeezing through an irritated crowd. Surely that was not the first time the ground staff member had boarded passengers onto a plane?
My advice - if you are going to Kenya and there is no other choice, use Kenya Airways. Otherwise steer well clear. Flights taken: 21st December KQ0305 and KQ0762 7th January KQ0761 and KQ0310

Title:
I was flying from Abidjan to Nairobi in business class recently. Getting through the check in process was quick and easy - the guy at the business counter was friendly and efficient. He effortlessly changed my seat from the 1st row to the second to give me some more legroom. The ensuing chaos to navigate through passport and security control can not be blamed on Kenya Airways. At least I could recover with gin and tonic in the lounge which was bright, clean and relatively quiet.

This flight itself, however did not get off to a good start. Boarding was a disaster. Vague attempts were made to call business class passengers earlier than the rest but this was totally chaotic and meant that I was one of the last to board in the business area and there appeared to be absolutely no space left for my hand luggage. I just dumped it in front of me and waited for the cabin staff to arrange something for me which they did.

This was an overnight flight and the business class seats, whilst being bigger than in economy, only reclined a little - a joke for such a long, 6 hour flight when a chance to sleep should be expected.

At least we were offered a variety of drinks before take off. I certainly needed a glass of champagne.

Pretty soon into the flight I got my pre-ordered gin and tonic just a few minutes ahead of my meal - an "exotic" salad presumably so named because there were some pineapple pieces added for good measure. I chose a main course comprising beef strips, rice, carrots and spinach. This was quite spicy. The accompanying Shiraz red wine from an indeterminate country was OK.

Entertainment on this long flight comprised a film on the small screens emerging from the bulkhead which was laughable. I gave up and listened to my music on my smartphone.

Most of the rest of the flight was in pure darkness. I tried sleeping but it was impossible with the seats provided. I was so grateful that the pilot was able to catch up on a late take off.

Sorry to be so negative but the tickets for business class are not cheap. And other airlines have understood how to make such journeys much more comfortable. The one saving grace was the patience and constant smile on the lips of the cabin crew.

Title:
While already in Africa, some friends and I decided to take a short trip to Zanzibar over an extended weekend for about four days. Unfortunately, more than 1/3 of our trip ended up being spent in transit. I am thoroughly disappointed by the lack of professionalism and competence repeatedly displayed by the Kenya Airway agents in the Nairobi airport. Not only did they ruin a large portion of our vacation and cost us money, but from a business standpoint their inability to manage situations is proving costly to Kenya Airlines as well. I love flying with Skyteam and all their affiliates, specifically Delta and Air France, but my experience with Kenya Airlines has been a disappointment and does not meet the expected standards. We began our experience with Kenya Airways waiting on our flight to Zanzibar where we were to arrive at 8:10 am. There were five of us and together we were paying more than $1000 a night for an all-inclusive resort in Nungwi. The first flight to Nairobi was more than an hour late. I regret not checking Kenya Airlines performance rating for this flight prior to booking since it shows they have a "poor - 1 out of 5 stars" rating and are only on time 62% of the time. When we arrived in Nairobi we immediately went to the Kenyan Airlines counter, knowing we had missed our connection. The attendant at the counter told us there were not any other flights that would get us into Zanzibar that day and the only one available left close to midnight and we would arrive the next morning. We had asked if there were any other airlines they could check and put us on since we were able to find a few online. They continued to tell us no, they could not put us on any other airlines and there was nothing available with them. This was a lie and quite frankly, the people at the desk were not even looking for other options. They were content with simply doing the minimal amount of work, checking their cell phones while we were talking, and getting us away from their desk as their attitudes conveyed that we were annoying them simply by being inquisitive. After a bit of back and forth where we were not getting anywhere with the desk attendant we went to breakfast then downstairs to another Kenya Airlines desk. That was where we met Weddy - the most professional and helpful employee we have ever encountered with Kenya Airlines. We explained our predicament and she searched for alternative options, finding a flight leaving that evening with Precision Air (the same airline we had on our return flight that we booked directly through Kenya Airlines) and though we would still spend more than 12 hours in the airport, it would get us into Zanzibar about 11 p.m. Weddy had a long queue lined up and asked us to return in about an hour so she could work on the ticket after she sent some emails and verified the details.
Additionally, Weddy was the only person in the entire airport that understood what a queue was and managed to keep people actually in line and do her job in a proficient manner. The ability to keep people in a queue seemed lost on all your other employees as we would stand in line and random people would forgo the line walking straight up to the desk and the attendants would help them. When we returned later Weddy was able to get us the tickets - we still did not get to our hotel until almost midnight and lost that complete day, our excursion, and our all-inclusive amenities we paid for, but at least Weddy made the attempt to help us fix the issue and was courteous when doing so, unlike your other employees. But that was just the initial flight to Zanzibar - the return flight experience was worst.

When leaving the airport from Zanzibar Sept 4 the personnel at the counter (Precision Air) would not print both our boarding passes, even though we received both our passes on the way in a couple days prior. They told us we had to get them at the desk in Nairobi. We had a 1 hr and 15 min layover and immediately went to the desk to get our tickets. Of course the queue was very long and half the customers ignored the it and walked right up to the desk - which the Kenya Airline employees did not seem to care about and simply helped whomever was in front of them. And by helped I mean again spent the majority of the time talking on their cell phones or texting people in the middle of a customer's complaint/issue. Two of our group attempted to get their passes printed off at the Kiosk but were unable (probably because we were within the 1 hr window) so we all waited. When the first of our group arrived at the desk we still had just over 30 minutes before our flight left. We had already spent 30 minutes in line because of the horrible time management and inefficiency of the staff compounded by their inability to actually keep people in a queue. When we arrived at the desk the gentleman told us we missed our flight. Again, we still had 30 minutes to get to the flight and should have already been checked in when we checked in at the Zanzibar airport. They then told us even if we were first in line at the desk when the plane landed (an hour before takeoff) we still would not have been able to board the plane. Why not? Why would they sell us a ticket on Kenya Airways own website that was a fraud? The entire time we are talking with the desk people they are again, randomly talking to other customers who just walked up (like the outraged lady who was supposed to being going to one location but the Kenya Airways attendants booked her to the wrong country - I didn't really blame her), checking their phones, and essentially being some of the most atrocious customer service representatives imaginable. They were flippant and did not care. Having been at the desk or waiting in the queue for an hour, we were now about to miss the next leg of our vacation stuck in the airport again because of Kenya Airlines. Part of our group was with one attendant at the desk and the others were with the other attendant so they herded us together to one desk ... and promptly ignored us since there were about five other people crowded at the desk also demanding information and assistance. Finally another attendant walked up and told us they will put us in a hotel since they have no other flights until the next afternoon, 17 hours after we had landed, and we should walk to the immigration area and he will be right with us to help us. We go to the immigration area, fill out the paperwork, and wait ... and wait ... and wait. We go back to get him and he said he will be right there, but does not show up again and we wait. The man finally comes and gets us through immigration and now tells us to go downstairs and get a hotel. We find the hotel line and wait some more until Magdalyn at the desk is able to assist us. She was kind and very professional though, not any fault of her own, the hotels available were not in any way, shape or form five stars like we had been told. After booking our stay we were told to go outside to the shuttle. The shuttle is a large older bus and though 90% full when we arrived, we had to wait there until every single seat was taken which was well over 30 more minutes. Finally they were able to take us to our hotels (different people on the bus were staying at different hotels) and we checked in around 1 am, nearly four hours after we had landed. Our meals were provided and other than the hotel being outdated and loud, was fine for a night, it just seems a waste of money for Kenya Airlines in that this whole situation could have been avoided with a little proficiency in your customer service department, not to mention you had now wasted another complete day of ours. The next morning we got up, went to breakfast and immediately left again for the airport - this time with a private shuttle that was much better. We arrive just after 11 a.m. for a
2:50 p.m. flight. Do you think that flight was on time? Of course not. At 2:20 we are standing at the entrance to the seating area (in Nairobi you have to go through another desk to get to your gates specific seating area) and nobody was there. Thirty minutes later when our flight was supposed to be leaving, there was still not any Kenya Airline attendants to be seen. None of the screens in the airport were updated and our flight was still showing as "on time" - which was physically impossible since there was not even an airplane on our ramp. One of the airline attendants finally showed up and said we are delayed for approximately two more hours due to maintenance, but would not let us in the seating area so all the passengers just milled about outside or wandered down the terminal to find other seats. After getting to board, the flight staff was wonderfully fine and we had no issues with them, though none of the televisions in the headrest worked on the flights.

I understand that situations arise when traveling and flexibility is key - but I have an issue when those situations become acceptable norms and your Kenya Airlines staff remain aloof and complacent, further complicating the experience. Of what was supposed to be a relaxing 96 hour trip, 31 ADDITIONAL hours (I did not include the time we expected to spend when we booked our flights) were spent in Nairobi due to an utter failure by Kenya Airlines. Not to mention we lost an entire day of our vacation and all expenses incurred with it.

I sent an email to Kenya Airlines first and they sent me a completely professional and respectful reply back - though quit disparaging by stating "we sincerely regret the inconveniences caused to you as a result of the one hour delay of your flight from Djibouti to Nairobi." The one hour delay is NOT what this about.
qwuub: Spent 30+ hrs of a 96 hr trip stuck at airport due to inept customer service

Title:
The moment KQ sold their golden landing slot at LHR, I knew something was up and made several inquiries. Seems the overnight flight from Nairobi to Heathrow was so hot that the landing slot was sold to Qatar airlines,
Now KQ forced all those who had booked months in advance to change their return schedule from Nairobi to London and lose a day because the flight now leaves Nairobi at 9AM and arrives at Heathrow at 4PM.

I found the cabin service really gone down. Previously we used to get really good cabin service especially on long haul but now literally an entire aisle in economy is covered by one steward serving ALL meals - this takes ages and by the time they reach the seats at the back of the plane the passengers who were served first have not only finished their meals but fallen asleep.

I was appalled by the poor service. Blankets were not provided to everyone and lack of adequate meal option seem to be a common problem on both outbound and inbound flights.

I have been using KQ for the last 15 years and at one point it had surpassed the standards of BA but now for the first time KQ is taking short cuts - this reflects on its share price sadly.

I really hope the management focus on the quality it provides to its passengers and not just focusing on high air fares,

Title:
On the evening of 28 August, 2016 I arrived at the airport 3 hours before departure having already checked in online. I went straight to the self-check-in machines and within less than a minute printed my boarding card. All good.
Then the debacle began - it took me 1 hour and 20 minutes to check my bag (and that process took less than a minute). The airline that calls itself 'The Pride of Africa' has no facility for international travellers to drop their bags. You join the (extremely long) check-in queue and shuffle along whilst only TWO check-in attendants were on duty (out of 7 counters). That took 80 minutes.

I eventually found a supervisor who, when I asked her why the airline was treating their passengers like this, replied, whilst constantly scrolling down on her phone and without looking up 'I feel you'.
What on earth is that supposed to mean?
I then started talking to KQ on Facebook begging them to send more check-in personal. They also said sorry but did nothing.
I then sent many messages asking for an explanation (all available for the airline to see) but nothing was forthcoming.
I received a cut-and-paste-get-rid-of-this-passenger-quickly email apology which was utterly meaningless. I replied saying not good enough. I was then asked to log onto their customer services portal to continue the discussion. More hoops for what?
I am a member of the tourism industry in Kenya and am ashamed and heartbroken by the dismissive and dreadful service offered by the national airline. I don't think they care a hoot.
All well and good but I would urge any customers who have a choice to avoid flying KQ at all costs. If not, good luck with the queues and budget many hours for check-in and don't bother using preprinted boarding cards - just adds to your frustration.

Title:
After flying in from Montreal, Canada on June 23rd, I had a connecting flight London-Nairobi-Kilimanjaro with Kenya Airways KQ 101. In London, I double-checked with one of their employee to make sure my luggage was going straight to Kilimanjaro. After calling somebody in charge of luggage, the employee confirmed that was the final destination.

The plane ( a bit old with worn out seats) was delayed in London for 2 hours (we stayed in the plane in very hot conditions waiting for departure). I missed the connection on Flight KQ 0432 to Kilimanjaro. On my insistence, I was re-booked on Flight PW 722 with Precision Air that left the same morning at 8:00 am. When we got there 9 passenger did not have their luggage. Two of them, who we're climbing the Kilimanjaro the next day, had been given the same reassuring speech about their luggage in London...

Logically, I did not expect my luggage to be on that last flight (because of the short delay), but I expected it later on in the day. Unfortunately, it seems that it had never left London (according to information given by the company when they found it) and was redirected finally on June 27th 2016. I got it on June 29th 2016 fortunately because our tour operator(Simba Safari) had the courtesy to bring it where I was in my journey. Meanwhile, everyday from the 24th to the 27th of June, when we've called to have information, they said it was coming in the day...

Since I was leaving for a 7 day safari on the morning of June 25th, I went to buy some clothes.

A few days after my return home, I've sent a formal complaint by e-mail to the company, on July 12th 2016 and a following e-mail on July 29th 2016. Besides the automated reply mentioning an incident number and that the matter would be resolved by July 15th 2016, not a word from Kenya Airways.

I must say I was very disappointed by this first experience with Kenya Airways. Not only by the delayed luggage, but also by the fact that the connection to Kilimanjaro was not held, even though 15 to 20 people had to take that connection. As I mentioned before,I also had to insist on being booked on the next available flight that day, because they had decided to book me on a flight leaving at 4:00pm (some we're booked on a flight to Zanzibar at 11:30pm!). I would have spent another 9 hours uselessly at Nairobi Airport for a 50 minute flight.

I read that the company is restructuring. I think they should pay more attention to customer service if they want to maintain their clientele. That applies even after the flight.

In all fairness, through all these events, employees of Kenya Airways were always courteous.

My other flight (at the end of my safari) with Kenya Airways, Kilimanjaro-Nairobi-Zanzibar went without a glitch. The plane was a recent one and very nice.
qwuub: Not sure about "The pride of Africa".

Title:
I paid 3 months in advance for a return trip from JKIA to Malindi departing in the late afternoon on 4th August and returning on 10th August on the evening flight. Our experience was that Kenya Airways cancelled both of the flights we booked within 1 week of our departure and rebooked us on 5th Aug 08.00 and on 10th August at 09.00.
The first change meant that we had to book another night of accommodation in Nairobi and the second gave us the prospect of a 15hr layover at JKIA before our return flight to London. On the 3rd Aug we were informed by email that our 08.00 flight to Malindi had been cancelled and we were rebooked on a Jambo Jet flight at 09.40 on the 5th. During the evening of the 4th Aug our Jambo Jet flight time was changed to 11.00 back to 09.40 and then back to 11.00 in the space of 2 hours with the final change after 10pm when we were asleep. We ended up at the airport at 08.00 in case the flight was on time, the flight finally took off at around 13.30 and we arrived in Malindi nearly a day late which in a 6 day visit is quite significant. We rebooked our return flight from Mombasa in the evening of the 10th to avoid wasting another day of our holiday in JKIA. Kenya Airways is strong on communicating how sincere they are about the inconvenience caused by the series of changes however, not a single member of their staff expressed any regrets and no compensation of any sort was offered. The additional costs we incurred included a £60 taxi cost to get to Mombasa airport, in addition to the hotel in Nairobi plus the delayed arrival inconvenience. Title: Our Kenya Airways flight from Kilimanjaro Airport (JRO) to Livingstone Airport (LVI) via Nairobi (NBO) was booked by Air France Flying Blue team, through our Marriott Rewards redeemable points. I can honestly say that we were very impressed and loved flying Kenya Airways for the first-time within east-central and south-central flown part of our African Escapade.                                           The plane was super-clean, seats were spacious and comfortable, the food and beverages served were one of the best, and especially the whole-cashews snack-pouch was delightfully filling and tasty; they served the highest-quality, humongous-sized cashews we ever ate. The attendants were also cool about giving these snacks a few more extras to munch on with your drink. I saved a couple for later. The crew on-board were very friendly, had a good sense of humor and they were willing to assist you in every way they could. Bathrooms in the plane were the best I ever experienced flying domestic or anywhere international. With wider and deepest sinks I ever used in a flight and easy-operating sink-faucets like the ones at home, their bathrooms were the most spacious, cleanest and the best  on-board. We didn’t use Wi-Fi but I believe it was not offered on this flight. With comfortable seats we took a snooze instead.                                         We flew about an hour from JRO to NBO, and it was a little over 2-hour layover at Nairobi Airport where we had lunch at their new terminal opened early 2015. There were spacious lounges, cafes, restaurants, shops and had an easy access to nice bathrooms at all nearby Gates and exits throughout the new terminal at Nairobi Jomo Kenyatta International. They’ve made the terminal exceptionally easy to navigate, very convenient and the most comfortable I experienced on the continent. The Airport staff at our gate’s departure was very friendly, courteous, accommodating and most importantly very patient when we arrived slightly late. We were completely unaware, and did not know that we had to board a transit-bus at the tarmac from our departure-gate to the aircraft; they calmed our anxiety down and helped us board the bus in time, although we weren’t late or the last to board. Our onward flight to Livingstone was also very comfortable. On our return flight we stayed/slept overnight in Aspire Lounge of JK Nairobi Intl. Airport. At US$30 for 3-hrs., we paid $180 for 6-hrs for the three of us. The Lounge was comfortable with good food and drinks laid out on counters, a TV sitting area, and the night-host/attendant joined together armless sofa-chairs for us to sleep. There are no showers in Aspire Lounge, but it was a good lounge to get a bite to eat, grab a drink, relax/doze off, and the staff is willing to help you with anything.                                      When compared to taking any domestic flights within North American continent, we are quite impressed and pleased to say that on the African side of planet, the Kenya Airways flight, its crew and its Airport staff surpassed our expectations. Keep up the good work Team KA!
qwuub: “The Pride of Africa”, the Company-Logo is Right On…

Title:
Probably one of the best things about flying with this airline is the weight of luggage they allow. But do make sure that any one bag does not exceed 20 kg. This way you can have check in luggage of up to 40 kg and still have carry on luggage etc.
Although they are not rated as one of the top airlines of the world, it is a very convenient and cheaper option to fly long distances, although flights may be few and far apart, so make sure you book way in advance.
Also - be sure to wear very easy clothes as you will have to remove your shoes, belt and any other garment/ accessory that may contain metal EVEN when you just do a climb over at Kenyata airport in Nairobi. It may also be handy to have a small fold up bag ready that you can dump all the items you had to take off in so you can easily get them on the other side of the scanner. They do provide plastic baskets for this, but there are way too few of them and you may end up having to leave your stuff on the floor.
Should you have to wait some time at the airport I would advise that you have a few $US handy, since the restaurants do not have credit card facilities and the places that do are sometimes offline or the connection can be very slow.
My flight was cancelled at very short notice, and since I was a single traveler - they proposed to get me on a flight of their affiliated airline Ethiopian Air. This helped a lot and Ethiopian is not a bad low cost airline either. Should you encounter a problem like this, you may want to ask if they can move you over to Ethiopian Airways. I do however believe they can only do this for one or two passengers since they have to be sure of availability of seats.

Title:
The good stuff: The entertainment doesn't stop for take off or landing, you can watch movies all along. Worth bringing your own headset and an airplane adapter cheap of ebay, because the quality of sound on the headset provided is poor.

That's about all the positives.

First of all, the staff on the flight were plain rude. Zero communication skills. If you didn't quite catch what they said or wanted, they would just hover over you with a frown, without saying what they were after for the second time until you magically discovered what was going on. For example when serving hot beverages tea and coffee were served couple minutes apart. No big deal. The cart is approaching, I'm saying coffee please and put the cup on the tray. Not a word. Just a frown. Could I get some coffee please? So they would not say straight away that it's gonna be served separately and I should take mu cup back, they would just stand there with an impatient expression growing.

The attendants plain ignore the 'require assistance' light. My friend had it on for 12 minutes, no reaction whatsoever, an attendant passed her by with a tea pot but did not bother to stop and ask what's going on. Fortunately, all my friend needed was a drink, so having noted these are being served she switched the light off. Had she needed anything more serious she might as well forget it unless you start kicking and screaming that you need help. Which gets awkward if you're not dying, but just need some discreet assistance.

Food was ok, the main course was a bit too salty, but I could live with that. The croissant on the connecting flight to Mombasa tasted like genuine English mould, scraped off the cellar wall. At least that's what it smelled of. I'm not sure it was stored in improper conditions or what the cause was. You don't get drinks outside of your set meal times (the light gets ignored if you turn it on) so bring your own water even if you feel you're not going to need some, as the air gets really dry on this long flight.

Title: This was my first time travelling on Kenya Airways and I was a bit apprehensive but I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. The check-in was smooth and efficient, I especially liked the fact that I got 2 bags of 23kg each checked in luggage and the same applied to my return flight which was with a different airline. The aircraft between Nairobi and Cape Town had leather seats which I didn't expect but I really liked. The in-flight entertainment didn't work but to be honest I really didn't mind. The screen is quite small though and I most probably wouldn't have enjoyed watching a movie on it anyway. The food is average but adequate. Don't expect any of the luxuries that you would experience when flying with bigger, more popular airlines, you get what you pay for.  If you are looking for a clean, comfortable, value for money airline, then this is it.  I will definitely fly with them again.

Title:
Our flight from Nairobi to Bangkok was cancelled and we only found out after queueing 30 minutes to drop off our bags after checking in online. There was no communication at all to inform us prior to us reaching the airport. The first ground staff whom we encountered could only tell us he did not know anything, his supervisor was not around and we were to wait for further instructions. He seemed extremely eager to go off duty.
We were kept waiting for another hour for a lady staff to show up and issue hotel accommodation vouchers. When she showed up, she just took our boarding passes and wrote out everything by hand slowly. When we asked what other flights we could take, she just carried on writing out vouchers for other passengers, ignoring us until we pressed further. The reply was extremely unhelpful. We were to wait till tomorrow morning to check in and we would find out what flight we could take. By then, this was already 11pm. We had been at the airport since 930pm. This lady's name was Immaculate. She was dismissive and basically displayed an attitude that was highly unsuitable for customer service.
We waited another hour to get to the only staff who was actually helping stranded passengers. Unfortunately, he was stuck helping a group of passengers check in their bags for close to an hour. The poor staff, Derrick, was left alone to deal with the crisis as all his colleagues on duty at that time just ditched him and disappeared despite the fact that there were more than 20 people waiting.
He tried to get us flights back to Singapore but the only option that would get us back in time for our commitments was to transit in 7 hours in Mumbai. Imagine if we had listened to Immaculate and just showed up the next day only to realise that we might have been stranded yet again.
By now, it was close 2 am after everything had been sorted out. We went to the bus provided to bring us to the hotel which was supposed a 5 star hotel as told to us by the ground staff but the situation became even more farcical from this point onwards. We were told it was only 10 to 15 minutes. After 30 minutes of driving, the bus driver brought us to the first Pride Hotel. It was discovered that it was the wrong one after some passengers. The same thing occurred when we were driven to the second. Only by the third try was it correct cos they have exhausted all the options for Pride Hotel in Nairobi. By this time, it was 240am.
Check in was a mess with tired passengers trying to get rooms. When we got to our rooms, there was no bedsheets and pillowcases. When my friend asked for them, the hotel receptionist said then you can give up your rooms to this couple who did not get one (yes, Kenya Airways actually issued hotel vouchers but did not Ensure that there were enough rooms for stranded passengers). Pride Hotel is definitely not a 5 star hotel.
By the time we got to sleep, it was 3am. We had to leave the hotel by 5am to catch our 7am flight out of Nairobi. The bus to the airport left only at 525am cos we were all waiting for one passenger. By the time we got to the airport, it was 610am and we needed to board at 630am. This meant a mad rush through all different checkpoints.
We made it to our flight barely on time.
By the time we landed in Mumbai, I was having gastric issues, no thanks to the lack of sleep, stress and dehydration cos it took very long to get water on board the flight. However, we were stuck in the transit area and were told we needed to wait til 730pm to get into the area where we could get access to food. This was at 430pm. And this reason for this was because Kenya Airways did not issue our boarding passes for the connecting flight. Thankfully, the ground staff at Mumbai airport were much more helpful. They arranged for an airport doctor to see me and they issued temporary boarding passes so that I could at least get food which Kenya Airways did not pay for despite the fact that it was their fault we were diverted.
The whole chain of events on that night/day was a debacle. Having flights cancelled is usual and cannot be avoided but what could have been avoided is the lack of apologies and the desire to at least help stranded passengers get home. Kenya Airways should look into more training for staff in managing crises especially for this particular staff called Immaculate and have a proper SOP. It only managed to make tired and confused passengers angrier and angrier through the long waits, lack of information and apologies, and avoidable mistakes at different points.
qwuub: Horrible service recovery for flight cancellation

Title:
I have travelled with KQ for the last few years on a monthly basis between the UK and Nairobi on business.

The airline used to be really good. A couple of years ago I'd have chosen KQ over most of its competitors, including European and Asian operators.

I'm very sad to say though that there has been a marked decline in service quality over the past 12 months, and I'm now at the stage where I am scoping alternatives.

I believe there have been cuts in staff, and this is clearly showing now on the 'shop floor'. The customer services desks in Jomo Kenyata Airport are simply awful. What should be simple queries are turning into absolute epics because staff seem to lack even basic knowledge on how to deal with straightforward everyday queries. It's not the fault of the staff - it's a clear training gap.

Last month I had a flight cancelled for the umpteenth time for 'operational reasons' (that old chestnut. The staff informed us we would be put up in a hotel over night. The hotel was less than a mile from the airport. From informing us of the cancellation to getting us into that hotel took them 6 hours!? This delay was entirely down to the customer services staff not having a clue what they were supposed to do.

The online 'help desk' is also utterly useless. Email queries go unanswered. The supposed 'live chat' service goes unanswered. When you do get an advisor, they are rarely able to answer your query satisfactorily.

I have umpteen similar tales. KQ are a shadow of their former selves. As soon as I scope a worthwhile alternative, I shall be taking my business elsewhere.
qwuub: Once a good airline, now in real decline

I explained the difference in our treatment at London Heathrow Airport and was again, told that I could purchase extra legroom, if available, once in Nairobi for our flight to London as it was all controlled by staff at Nairobi airport.  I was told that IF there were any unpurchased extra legroom seats on our connecting flight, staff MIGHT consider allocating them to my family, but that was not guaranteed. I had to argue the point that my family physically could not fit in economy seats, that there was no way to purchase extra legroom when making my reservation, that I had called the airline in advance to try to arrange this and that it was not the fault of the traveller for being too tall to fit in economy seats.  My family and I were also seated separately, in different rows for our return flights, despite asking at check in to be seated together.  I had to argue to have our seats changed to sitting together after the lady at check in had lied repeatedly saying that the flight was full.  A truly rubbishy service from KA in Kenya.After much arguing at Mombasa airport with a manager named J Ananga, I was permitted to purchase extra legroom seats at Mombasa and not have to wait until our arrival at Nairobi even though we had had free extra legroom seats on our outbound flights. Title: I am by no means a "frequent flyer" but I have to say I found the whole experience of Kenya Airways really good. We were on flight KQ101 Heathrow to Nairobi on a 787 dreamliner, I had chosen seats in row 17 right over the wing as I had read this was the quietist area to be in. There was an impressive choice of films to watch, the food served was quite tasty and the seats, considering this was economy, were quite comfortable. The first leg of our trip was a 7.5 hour flight, followed by a layover of about 5 hours at Nairobi before boarding an Embraer 190, flight KQ780 for a 2.5 hour flight on to Livingstone. Overall I was very impressed with the airline and can definitely recommend them to anybody contemplating a trip to Africa. We booked about 5 months in advance and got our flights for <£500 each, return. For those of you who are plane spotters, the 787 was aircraft no. 5Y-KZH and the Embraer 190 was 5Y-FFG. You can track flight KQ101 on flightradar24 every day from LHR at 19.00 gmt.
